commit_message:
Workaround broken pyroute2 0.5.13

The pyroute2 package version 0.5.13 introduced a bug[1] that breaks
amphora. Unfortunately neutron needs a different fix that is in 0.5.13,
so we are going to work around the problem until we can get pyroute2 fixed.

This patch uninstalls pyroute2 and installs version 0.5.12.

[1] https://github.com/svinota/pyroute2/issues/724

Change-Id: I365d719810de792213da47ebafa46e7e0fd2e9fa

commit_message:
Generated passthrough_whitelist shall use all the user_configs fields

Earlier, the derived pci passthrough whitelist includes the address,
vendor and product details only. This is not sufficient for nova to
allocate the VFs to the guests. Now, all the fields of the user_config
shall be used in the derived passthrough_whitelist. Only either of 'address'
or 'devname' shall be provided in passthrough_whitelist, and since the
'address' fields are must have to specify the induvidual VF's, the
'devname' is removed if present.

Change-Id: I5a337a67893241e1443ca2c3721f4c9dd78b95c8
(cherry picked from commit d5820dba4abc9fc531b4155cb9f95038f956710c)

[{'created': '2020-07-28 19:12:25.000000000', 'message': "[ci] Remove explicit compression of log files

Compression is not needed post [1], explicit
compression renders them non-browsable.

This commit applies to legacy style jobs that
will soon be replaced with zuulv3 native jobs;
however, fixing it isn't terrible, and we
can use this fix for stable branches
where zuulv3 native jobs may not come for a
while.

commit_message:
[ci] Remove explicit compression of log files

Compression is not needed post [1], explicit
compression renders them non-browsable.

This commit applies to legacy style jobs that
will soon be replaced with zuulv3 native jobs;
however, fixing it isn't terrible, and we
can use this fix for stable branches
where zuulv3 native jobs may not come for a
while.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-January/011875.html
Co-Authored-By: yatinkarel <ykarel@redhat.com>

Change-Id: Icd4f9dc435a807f6f729e4eb2d4df4b282ec79ac
Signed-off-by: Goutham Pacha Ravi <gouthampravi@gmail.com>
(cherry picked from commit 770e57ff3192c3828b2d3162ae1f132d3858997b)
(cherry picked from commit 531e810526843a6c152543396394068dd9873ad6)
(cherry picked from commit afb63e9db8dc470ee93f8532061fdafd19a7c93a)
(cherry picked from commit 2b16184da884820d579f02eff0910054e4041170)
(cherry picked from commit 6be3eda9f50d3ea67f34338c26fbb6143cc323f3)

Even if we plan on using a module, this code work:

http://pastebin.test.redhat.com/887778

with that in place we get 0% ping loss:

http://pastebin.test.redhat.com/887779

Note that in 887778 we only use layered product for osp16.  As ansible is a thing only since osp16, the tripleo-ansible should aim to port only the layered product code, and don't handle the non-layer product part."}, {'account_id': 6681, 'date': '2020-07-27 16:19:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> Even if we plan on using a module, this code work:

 > http://pastebin.test.redhat.com/887779
 > 
 > Note that in 887778 we only use layered product for osp16.  As
 > ansible is a thing only since osp16, the tripleo-ansible should aim
 > to port only the layered product code, and don't handle the
 > non-layer product part.

layered packaging (i.e. involves rhosp-openvswitch) is, afaik, not available for centos so we may not be able to remove that special handling of the non-layered case yet."}, {'account_id': 8297, 'date': '2020-07-27 18:42:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 8297, 'date': '2020-07-27 18:43:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 8297, 'date': '2020-07-27 18:52:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 8297, 'date': '2020-07-27 19:51:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 8297, 'date': '2020-07-27 21:38:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

commit_message:
Add openvswitch special treatment to update too.

Openvswitch package update can be disruptive during update too.  So we
factor out the code used for upgrade to re-use for update and
undercloud update.

We also fix a issue where yum/yumdownloader is not available anymore.
This cause the special treatment to not happen anymore what not matter
what.

Instead of duplicating the ansible sequence, this has been ported to a
ansible module that replicate the action defined in the templates.

We also make sure to not try to restart the openvswitch service if
nothing has been changed during the ovs upgrade task.  This cover two
cases.  First, it's an optimization, if nothing has been done, we
don't need to check the service.  Second, and most importantly, if ovs
isn't installed (this can happen on some minimal installation) then we
don't try to restart the non-existent service.

We keep the tasks at step 3 that make sure again that the openvswitch
service is started.  This is a failsafe and as such we ignore any
error there.  This also support the overcloud-minimal type of
installation.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/742968
Change-Id: I4fde50e353ab7b2e6b03d963f585f6abe35ca32d
Closes-Bug: #1888651
Related-Bug: #1888821

commit_message:
POC, citellus support

	Citellus (https://citellus.org) is a framework for running simple-to-write bash scripts that can automate the
	detection of known issues. Reporting is done either via CLI, or via json that can be parsed by other tools.

	html is provided to read from a http server the json and graphically provide the status of the checked system.

	Most of the support is for OSP rules but anything relevant can be written/scripted and run against either
	sosreport  or a 'live' system.

Change-Id: Ia31c598372f2dabe4125650e83e410848a599896

commit_message:
[k8s] Use helm upgrade --install in deployment loop

Sometimes, the chart may fail to deploy, e.g. if the worker node is not
ready before chart deployment times out. Retry until status is deployed.

Story: 2007514
Task: 40276

Change-Id: I8fd5cc154e86006e9139d5ac5f282d0b460eca37
(cherry picked from commit a008e3b44f8610675d50f8aef9c576133c707814)

commit_message:
Run validation only if overcloud exists.

When no overcloud is deployed, the openstack-endpoint.yaml validations
fail. This patch re-orders couple of tasks and runs the failing task for
unavailable endpoints only when an overcloud exists.

Change-Id: I174b5a239a7c1ab7b93323654a417db8f087bc27
Story: #2002061
(cherry picked from commit 864ab1d64d36562d163bf407d842e190c0e27531)

commit_message:
Read mounts from /proc/mounts instead of running mount

When creating multiple concurrent volumes, there's a lock
that prevents mount from returning quickly. Reading /proc/mounts
is way faster.

Change-Id: If31d120955eb216823a55005fdd3d24870aa6b9a
Closes-Bug: #1856889
(cherry picked from commit f2409608473c06892b087e44e0041c9ade3f9924)
(cherry picked from commit a8190cd60b59dedb11a8ed27d236d81adee3255d)
(cherry picked from commit 7168bdce5bcdf3f1a27c6fc9f998c1f3f5364f3d)

commit_message:
Remove translation sections from setup.cfg

These translation sections are not needed anymore, Babel can
generate translation files without them.

Change-Id: I07cac802653e5b266d598387e72f5556936551e9

> Looks like it's getting picked up fine in the unit test jobs:
 > 
 > https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/f6da81ec2f03453ca7576bc4f07a910c/log/job-output.txt#346
 > 
 > But I don't see the equivalent in the tempest logs. Maybe there is
 > a problem with the way the tempest test is defined and it is
 > missing that bindep step?

Yeah, for devstack tox based jobs or unit tests bindep is handled with 'bindep' ansible role
- https://opendev.org/zuul/zuul-jobs/src/branch/master/roles/bindep

but if you want to install all bindep packages then you have two way to do that:
1. via devstack plugin by adding bindep.txt under devstack/files/ and then devstack look for it and install those packages.
- https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack/src/branch/master/doc/source/plugins.rst#user-content-bindep

2. use -bindep option but that needs to be done in devstack for known lib

let's try the first option and devstack should install all mentioned deps."}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2020-07-27 17:30:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

 > but if you want to install all bindep packages then you have two

 > 1. via devstack plugin by adding bindep.txt under devstack/files/
 > and then devstack look for it and install those packages.
 > - https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack/src/branch/master/doc/source/plugins.rst#user-content-bindep
 > 
 > 2. use -bindep option but that needs to be done in devstack for
 > known lib
 > 
 > let's try the first option and devstack should install all
 > mentioned deps.

I realized now os-brick is lib not devstack plugin so 1st option is not valid. we can go with 2nd option but need some modification in devstack also.

We need to add the -bindep support in _install_lib_from_source () method which can pass the same in setup_dev_lib ()
- https://github.com/openstack/devstack/blob/94ca9f6756e7b677b1ee3fd2e32b555447e950dd/lib/libraries#L75

And then we can mention -bindep for os-brick at below

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-07-24 03:08:50.000000000', 'message': "Replace sg_scan with lsscsi to get '[H:C:T:L]'

The current get_device_info uses sg_scan to get device info but it only
returns HLU number lower than 255 due to bug#1793259. sg_scan was
designed for old days when 255 LUNs were enough. However we now have
requirement to support HLU number greater than 255. Since lsscsi doesn't
have the limit of 255, we should use lsscsi to get device info.

The 'device' of get_device_info can be of 2 types:
o /dev/disk/by-path/xxx, which is a symlink to /dev/sdX
o /dev/sdX

sg_scan can take any device name but lsscsi only show /dev/sdx names.
So if the device is a symlink, we use the device name it links to,
otherwise we use it directly.
Then get the device info '[H:C:T:L]' by comparing the device name with the
last column of lsscsi output
Also lsscsi doesn't require privilege.

Change-Id: I867c972d9f712c0df4260ebc8211b786006ed7a2
Closes-bug: #1793259
"}, {'created': '2020-07-24 05:43:38.000000000', 'message': "Replace sg_scan with lsscsi to get '[H:C:T:L]'

The current get_device_info uses sg_scan to get device info but it only
returns HLU number lower than 255 due to bug#1793259. sg_scan was
designed for old days when 255 LUNs were enough. However we now have
requirement to support HLU number greater than 255. Since lsscsi doesn't
have the limit of 255, we should use lsscsi to get device info.

The 'device' of get_device_info can be of 2 types:
o /dev/disk/by-path/xxx, which is a symlink to /dev/sdX
o /dev/sdX

sg_scan can take any device name but lsscsi only show /dev/sdx names.
So if the device is a symlink, we use the device name it links to,
otherwise we use it directly.
Then get the device info '[H:C:T:L]' by comparing the device name with the
last column of lsscsi output
Also lsscsi doesn't require privilege.

Change-Id: I867c972d9f712c0df4260ebc8211b786006ed7a2
Closes-bug: #1793259
"}, {'created': '2020-07-24 14:05:57.000000000', 'message': "Replace sg_scan with lsscsi to get '[H:C:T:L]'

returns HLU number lower than 255 due to bug#1793259. sg_scan was
designed for old days when 255 LUNs were enough. However we now have
requirement to support HLU number greater than 255. Since lsscsi doesn't
have the limit of 255, we should use lsscsi to get device info.

The 'device' of get_device_info can be of 2 types:
o /dev/disk/by-path/xxx, which is a symlink to /dev/sdX
o /dev/sdX

sg_scan can take any device name but lsscsi only show /dev/sdx names.
So if the device is a symlink, we use the device name it links to,
otherwise we use it directly.
Then get the device info '[H:C:T:L]' by comparing the device name with the
last column of lsscsi output

commit_message:
Replace sg_scan with lsscsi to get '[H:C:T:L]'

The current get_device_info uses sg_scan to get device info but it only
returns HLU number lower than 255 due to bug#1793259. sg_scan was
designed for old days when 255 LUNs were enough. However we now have
requirement to support HLU number greater than 255. Since lsscsi doesn't
have the limit of 255, we should use lsscsi to get device info.

The 'device' of get_device_info can be of 2 types:
o /dev/disk/by-path/xxx, which is a symlink to /dev/sdX
o /dev/sdX

sg_scan can take any device name but lsscsi only show /dev/sdx names.
So if the device is a symlink, we use the device name it links to,
otherwise we use it directly.
Then get the device info '[H:C:T:L]' by comparing the device name with the
last column of lsscsi output
Also lsscsi doesn't require privilege.

Depends-on: https://review.opendev.org/743548
Change-Id: I867c972d9f712c0df4260ebc8211b786006ed7a2
Closes-bug: #1793259

commit_message:
Adapt NP tests to new CRD format

This commit adapts network policy tests to new KuryrNetworkPolicy CRD
format. This includes splitting TestNetworkPolicy class into two
versions and a bit of refactoring to allow that.

Change-Id: Id303620090df194297e16384d3522c3e3bb2ca58

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-06-02 23:32:53.000000000', 'message': "[WIP]Fix proxy issue for etcd and kubelet

When the cloud behind a proxy, podman needs to access the dockerhub
via proxy to pull the image, so the proxy settings need to be export
to etcd systemd file as well. We're setting the heat-params as
environment file for k8s components already.

But there is a side effect, because CIDR of fixed subnet are vary
for different clusters, so the subnet CIDR should be added into
NO_PROXY list.

Task: 39916
Story: 2006459

Change-Id: I4dba79e04abe38b9806e847348d3dd77ef96bee5

commit_message:
Fix proxy issue for etcd and k8s

When the cloud is behind a proxy, podman needs to access the dockerhub
via proxy to pull the image, so the proxy settings need to be exported
to etcd systemd file as well. We're setting the heat-params as
environment file for k8s components already.

Besides, because CIDR of fixed subnet vary for different clusters,
so the subnet CIDR should be added into NO_PROXY list. Otherwise,
it will affect the communication between etcd members and also the
communication between k8s components.

Task: 39990
Story: 2007768

Change-Id: I4dba79e04abe38b9806e847348d3dd77ef96bee5

commit_message:
improve error messages during node lookup failures

The error messages reported on the console when the agent can't find
its node do not give enough information to debug the cause of the
failure. This change adds some basic details like the URL of the API
server and the addresses of the node being sought there.

Change-Id: Ia54faf05c80159d1d5fde0b222627c673f1cffe3

commit_message:
Add TODO to switch to new style rbd commands

The old variants will likely go away at some point. Leave a breadcrumb
here for future people trying to figure out why things broke.

Change-Id: I0c783313207b3f402b274360ee791c343030f781
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Update tox.ini to latest settings

This updates the minversion used in tox.ini to be a more recent version
to match other openstack project's settings. It also drops the out of
date defaults and replaces them with venv since there are not actually
any unit test environments to run. The only useful environment is venv,
so the default target will now just create the venv as a shortcut.

Change-Id: I58a606c5b923c27475e57a3839c493506e1d0774
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

subject: Fix README to be proper RST syntax
messages: [{'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2020-07-27 15:11:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2020-07-27 15:16:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:\n\nA new release should be done after this is merged since the last release failed to upload to PyPi due to this issue.'}, {'account_id': 1736, 'date': '2020-07-30 20:24:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-07-27 15:11:44.000000000', 'message': 'Fix README to be proper RST syntax

The README file was in RST, but had a formatting issue with the title.
The usage of the README is setup was incorrectly setting the content
type to markdown, rather than RST. This seems to have caused our twine
check to validate the package as fine, but PyPi apparently checks
package metadata a different way and rejected the package upload due to
issues with the README file.

This corrects the RST syntax, renames the file from txt to rst to
accurately reflect its content type, and updates the settings up
setup.py to correctly report the content as RST.

Change-Id: I5135a709410372aa938446563e8eca70b5eea985
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Fix README to be proper RST syntax

The README file was in RST, but had a formatting issue with the title.
The usage of the README is setup was incorrectly setting the content
type to markdown, rather than RST. This seems to have caused our twine
check to validate the package as fine, but PyPi apparently checks
package metadata a different way and rejected the package upload due to
issues with the README file.

This corrects the RST syntax, renames the file from txt to rst to
accurately reflect its content type, and updates the settings up
setup.py to correctly report the content as RST.

Change-Id: I5135a709410372aa938446563e8eca70b5eea985
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Branchful C8 Train jobs

With this patch we are adding Centos8 version of train branchful jobs
to run against CI branchless repo.

Once these C8 train jobs will get stable then we will remove
corresponding C7 train jobs in a follow up patch.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/742645/

Change-Id: I209754fefe18a2f26d7159547e8a92f5ab8f6eb6
Story: https://tree.taiga.io/project/tripleo-ci-board/us/1704

commit_message:
Update tox.ini to latest settings

This updates the minversion used in tox.ini to be a more recent version
to match other openstack project's settings. It also drops the out of
date defaults and replaces them with venv since there are not actually
any unit test environments to run. The only useful environment is venv,
so the default target will now just create the venv as a shortcut.

Change-Id: I416ed1cc997cd49029cf8fec31b30df5f4179ff2
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Remove universal wheel setting

We should no longer be creating universal wheels. This drops the
settings from setup.cfg.

Change-Id: I264dec21ef3407b78d8b26c91a49063d88a48674
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

The README file was in RST, but had a formatting issue with the title.
The usage of the README is setup was incorrectly setting the content
type to markdown, rather than RST. This seems to have caused our twine
check to validate the package as fine, but PyPi apparently checks
package metadata a different way and rejected the package upload due to
issues with the README file.

This corrects the RST syntax, renames the file from txt to rst to

setup.py to correctly report the content as RST.

Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Fix README to be proper RST syntax

The README file was in RST, but had a formatting issue with the title.
The usage of the README is setup was incorrectly setting the content
type to markdown, rather than RST. This seems to have caused our twine
check to validate the package as fine, but PyPi apparently checks
package metadata a different way and rejected the package upload due to
issues with the README file.

This corrects the RST syntax, renames the file from txt to rst to
accurately reflect its content type, and updates the settings up
setup.py to correctly report the content as RST.

Change-Id: I809b3964d1f4d239ea60f953a7cdcbcc9c9a98ff
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Generate a play per step for external_deploy_tasks

external_deploy_tasks will now be written out in per step files in the
config download directory. This will allow including the task files for
a specific step only at that step, and saving time by not having to skip
so many tasks.

Change-Id: I7ded2cb74afe73eab5c423fcb31ec9046ea47790
(cherry picked from commit eddc1e60941b96310d96a26bfb8d403993547249)

commit_message:
Enable vnc consoles in tempest

We had a regression in vnc consoles awhile back due to a change in
upstream noVNC from the master branch.

This enables vnc consoles in tempest so that we will be able to add the
novnc tests to our jobs to help catch future issues.

Related-Bug: #1822676

Change-Id: Iecdc53eae94d3556b41155f0aa839549c531c2e6

Aug 20 15:51:51.748757 ubuntu-bionic-rax-dfw-0010301045 neutron-server[10886]: WARNING oslo_service.service [-] pid 11009 not in child list
Aug 20 15:51:58.757499 ubuntu-bionic-rax-dfw-0010301045 neutron-server[10886]: INFO oslo_service.service [-] Child 11008 killed by signal 11
Aug 20 15:51:58.758384 ubuntu-bionic-rax-dfw-0010301045 neutron-server[10886]: WARNING oslo_service.service [-] pid 11008 not in child list

And in syslog around that time:

Aug 20 15:51:51 ubuntu-bionic-rax-dfw-0010301045 kernel: neutron-server:[11009]: segfault at d0 ip 000055aee5847546 sp 00007ffed6640b10 error 4 in python2.7[55aee5716000+301000]'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2020-07-30 20:12:42.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
requirements: move to using psycopg2-binary

The psycopg2-binary package is much more practical for development
and testing and it does not require to have build tooling and dev
headers in order to function properly.

In addition, the version has been bumped to 2.8 which means that
we can drop some of the DeprecationWarning filtering we had in
our test logging.

Depends-On: Ic765931f7362a1be970c4a2b6ff3b7051384b321
Change-Id: I19ebbbd39745130cf8de7bf95fcc4890b366962d

commit_message:
port: drop host-id and device-id

The host-id and device-id were meant to be removed in 2017 so
they are due to being removed.

Also, there were quite a few references to device-id instead
of device which are fixed in this patch.  This should enable
resetting the device_id to an empty string.

Change-Id: I4e70497836dbc1429e87c5add4eec0ac1a80b89f

zuul: add cross-repo jobs for openstack-ansible

This job is useful in testing OpenStack Ansible with Nova, more
specifically in testing a deployment with the in-tree placement.

commit_message:
console: refactor token parsing code into token_plugin

websockify has introduced the concept of token plugins which can
be called with a token value and expect to return a host and port
pair.

This eliminates a lot of redundant code that we maintained to
detect tokens which exists upstream.

Change-Id: I0ea8da1a20480853dd896a91929152468e6f8bbf

messages:
[{'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-05-09 17:04:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 23498, 'date': '2019-05-09 18:15:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Testing completed on the zVM Driver CI system check-nova pipeline.  To recheck only the zVM driver plugins, submit a comment with only zvm: recheck in the comment. Contact information: zvmosci@us.ibm.com. For information see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/ZVMDriver.

- check-nova-master http://extbasicopstackcilog01.podc.sl.edst.ibm.com/test_logs/jenkins-check-nova-master-31656 : SUCCESS in 1h 10m 22s'}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2019-05-09 19:18:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

For rechecking only on the Cloudbase Nova Hyper-V CI, add a review comment with run-Cloudbase Nova Hyper-V CI

- nova http://cloudbase-ci.com/nova/658158/1 : FAILURE in 2h 13m 01s'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-05-09 20:50:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

IIUC this is intended to work like:

- Admin specifies in conf some optional cpu features they want to be able to enable on a per-instance basis.
- Driver exposes those features as traits.
- Flavor/image optionally specifies such traits as required.
- If trait is required, placement will ensure instance lands on capable host (this part is free).
- Driver looks for each optional feature's trait in the flavor/image. If it's there, the flag will be enabled in the guest config; if not it will be disabled.

This is in contrast to the extra_flags, whose features are always turned on in the guest config.

Do I have that right?"}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-05-09 23:28:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Yup.  That's exactly the general intention overall."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-07-08 15:54:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Coming back to this...

Seems like an interesting idea. A blueprint and short spec would be appropriate to foster broader discussion. Thanks mnaser.'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2020-07-30 20:11:26.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-09 17:04:56.000000000', 'message': '[rfc] ability to use optional cpu flags

Change-Id: I5798d3ab09fe37feb9112ec36f08d79f3d3cc46c
'}]
commit_message:
[rfc] ability to use optional cpu flags

Few questions:
- how big is the generated image compared to the original one?
- the solution is really tied to the specific repository. Would it make more sense to dynamically find the packages without hardcoding the name of the .repo file? It would make it easier to share the code. For example, using an aptitude query on Ubuntu and yum with some disable-repo/enable-repo list available on CentOS/RHEL.
- another alternative could be creating a local mirror, which is slightly less efficient (packages need to be installed anyway, but you can use apt-mirror (Ubuntu) and rsync (CentOS/RHEL).'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2017-08-28 14:07:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified-1

commit_message:
Enable the ability to cache packages

For certain environments, the access to internet is not quick
and certain plugins require downloading a large amount of packages
on cluster start.

This patch adds the option to download the packages and store them
inside the image, avoiding the download of the packages at deploy
time.  This results in larger images but avoids the large amount
of downloads on boot.

Change-Id: I91426aa719fef2b84c7add666c5bdf353a3a8ec7

commit_message:
ironic: de-compose inventory

The current Ironic inventory assumes that a lot of things are
integrated together.  It's not implicitly required that the inspector
DHCP server is co-located with the inspector API service.

It's also not implicitly required that the conductor lives on the API
nodes, due to the fact that it's possible the control plane does not
speak directly to the management endpoints of Ironic-managed nodes.

Change-Id: I3fa92249e790f8823e89f404c0d0a6066bc2d616

commit_message:
virtualenv: use native python module

Due to the fact we use Python 3 everywhere, let's just use the venv
module instead of the old virtualenv binary.

Remove installation of the virtualenv distro package.

Change-Id: I15969b9d450cce6d36dbdfdbcc0ab7886e765a02

commit_message:
Add extra rootwrap filter

Due to the fact the binary name that we use inside OSA is python2
and there is no filter for it inside Neutron, killing processes
fails and migrating routers will result in the old keepalived procs
not being killed off.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/729844
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/704251
Change-Id: I1492af56e2e389b37cfc0e2818119729cd7ef733

messages:
[{'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-06-03 23:48:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 17799, 'date': '2019-06-04 00:02:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm not sure on this -- isn't the idea there that we don't want to be root, we want to be $container_user instead, so we sudo to it?"}, {'account_id': 17799, 'date': '2019-06-04 00:08:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Upon re-read, nevermind my previous comment.

But, this assumes the user attaching to the container is root, which may not be the case in an unprivileged container.'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-06-04 00:12:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

in the host as root to be able to run all these commands in the
first place.

Change-Id: Iaa6e2d3a149caec239be18380a1859247ff5c9e3

This patch avoids running su inside the container if the

specified container_user.

This is because lxc-attach behaviour by default will actually
give you a shell that matches the user which executes lxc-attach.

Change-Id: Iaa6e2d3a149caec239be18380a1859247ff5c9e3

"}, {'created': '2019-06-04 22:41:18.000000000', 'message': "connection: don't sudo if we're running as root

This patch avoids running su inside the container if the
remote_user which is connected to run the task matches the
specified container_user.

This is because lxc-attach behaviour by default will actually

Change-Id: Iaa6e2d3a149caec239be18380a1859247ff5c9e3

commit_message:
connection: don't sudo if we're running as root

This patch avoids running su inside the container if the
remote_user which is connected to run the task matches the
specified container_user.

This is because lxc-attach behaviour by default will actually
give you a shell that matches the user which executes lxc-attach.

Change-Id: Iaa6e2d3a149caec239be18380a1859247ff5c9e3

commit_message:
config: setup correct owner and group

We're not actually configuring any owner and group for the
config files which means that they can possibly be setup
as root:root which will break things.

Change-Id: I4974db647c305ae1876bb29d41ad411ed15c5978

subject: ci: use local connection inside AIO
messages:
[{'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-05-10 20:01:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 17799, 'date': '2019-05-10 20:06:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I'd prefer not to go this direction. connection: local works quite differently than the SSH connection plugin, and with a project of this size, there are quirky things that we can miss by using using local rather than SSH (as one would do in production envs). For one, local will use the venv python rather than the system python.

In general I use connection: local only for tasks that are intended to influence the deployment's ansible installation (ie. modifying the venv somehow, doing local operations related to the ansible deployment that will be done locally even in production, etc.)

This also won't work on container jobs since it disables the use of our SSH connection plugin."}, {'account_id': 17799, 'date': '2019-05-10 20:11:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

To address the concern about SSH overhead, maybe we could tune the SSH cipher in the gate to a faster one.'}, {'account_id': 17799, 'date': '2019-05-10 20:27:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> To address the concern about SSH overhead, maybe we could tune the
 > SSH cipher in the gate to a faster one.

Trying that out: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/658473/'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2020-07-30 20:09:25.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-10 20:01:16.000000000', 'message': "ci: use local connection inside AIO

When using an AIO, we don't really need to use SSH, we can just
use the local connection method to speed things up.

Change-Id: I73d6d1760e23aa538196829e2d79db148887c62a
"}]
commit_message:
ci: use local connection inside AIO

When using an AIO, we don't really need to use SSH, we can just
use the local connection method to speed things up.

Change-Id: I73d6d1760e23aa538196829e2d79db148887c62a

commit_message:
redhat: clean-up proxy settings properly

The tasks which removed the proxy settings did not actually
properly run because we didn't use quotes when specifiying
it.

This patch fixes this by making it a much cleaner solution
which leverages ini_file that will handle any sort of case to
remove it.

Change-Id: Ide6636f08774d62c83c1b111747eb24694fa68f6

commit_message:
Pass nova_ceph_client_uuid down to the ceph_client role

Ansible does not automatically import the variables of the parent
role when doing an include_role, therefore, the ceph_client role
fails to find the proper nova_ceph_client_uuid when being included.

This explicitly adds it and makes sure that it is passed down to
the role.

Change-Id: Id6c05d5a4262db7f416dde5e10d7001b537eb56d

IP or port for the management interface.  This patch adds two
variables which can be used to configure it.

subject: refactor: move config file drops into pre
messages:
[{'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2020-01-29 09:51:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 28619, 'date': '2020-01-29 11:21:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Maybe we should just get rid of symlinking, since this patch only partially resolve the issue - since pre-install till end of install step service will be not functional as well (since rootwrap files appear during venv setup which takes place later iirc).

So maybe instead of symlinking /etc we can fetch rootwrap files and place them with config_template - this will also make them overridable or really take a closer look about optimizing this process?

As moving all stuff to pre install makes it overcomplicated and placing configs after venv deployment makes some sense to me.'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2020-07-30 20:08:30.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-29 09:51:05.000000000', 'message': "refactor: move config file drops into pre

Inside our playbooks, we started doing a symbolic link to etc inside
the virtual environment when we started using smart sources.  However,
due to the fact we do this early, if the venv path changes, we'll link
to an empty folder which means that the existing deployment which is
still running has the policy file and all it's config pulled out from
beneath it until all the tasks between pre and post are done.

This moves the configuration higher up right after the virtualenv
symbolic link is created in order to minimize the amount of time
a service is running with no policy or configuration.

Change-Id: Ie5f65603b36fa85d3ce2bd849029a3ffcaf3afda
"}]
commit_message:
refactor: move config file drops into pre

Inside our playbooks, we started doing a symbolic link to etc inside
the virtual environment when we started using smart sources.  However,
due to the fact we do this early, if the venv path changes, we'll link
to an empty folder which means that the existing deployment which is
still running has the policy file and all it's config pulled out from
beneath it until all the tasks between pre and post are done.

This moves the configuration higher up right after the virtualenv
symbolic link is created in order to minimize the amount of time
a service is running with no policy or configuration.

Change-Id: Ie5f65603b36fa85d3ce2bd849029a3ffcaf3afda

epel: use vendored gpg keys

In order to avoid remote network issues, we vendor the GPG key
and install it locally.

subject: Passport Program v2 draft spec.
messages:
[{'account_id': 23924, 'date': '2018-07-18 09:17:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2018-07-19 00:33:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 21195, 'date': '2018-07-23 12:59:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

ad Regional Passports:
I don't think it is necessary. I watched the video with feedback from from last summit where the testers had the experience that clouds on other continents rejected them. It is not like we don't want customers from other continents. Just that a simple request for a trial from another continent >>without explanation, such as that it is a company expanding to Europe<< is very likely a scam. There are countries hosting lots of open proxies that we learned to be very cautious about.

ad Passport Homepage:
I would also add a row for non-OpenStack services available. (E.g. external firewall, DNS, non-Ironic bare metal, private OpenStack cloud)

ad Passport coupon codes:
What if we want to give out coupons to our customers directly e.g. on e-mail request or on events not organized by the Foundation? Will we need another kind of coupon codes for a trial just for our cloud or will that be possible to arrange through the Passport central database? Our Passport landing page already has an Enter Voucher Code field. Having two of them could be confusing and what this paragraph proposes would lead to that solution with us.

ad Q1:
What if a customer is not satisfied with the cloud he/she initially chooses and wants to switch just after registering or after consuming only a small fraction of the trial? We could add one more API for account cancellation. The we could let the voucher code be used again. How to protect against someone skipping between clouds indefinitely? Once/if the blockchain solution is implemented, remaining credits could be tracked there.

ad Q2:
We use a low quota and 1 weeks time. Both can be extended upon user request. We did it the same way with VPS trial before and some users really asked.

Even if there is a limit in dollar value, the low quota is a must, because some of the Passport users we received immediately launched cryptocurrency mining on all CPUs available to them. If we gave them the possibility to use the highest flavors, they would clog our compute nodes and annoy paying users."}, {'account_id': 13587, 'date': '2018-08-30 15:29:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 23924, 'date': '2018-08-31 11:35:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(3 comments)

Thanks for the comments Tomas and JD. See comments inline JD. 

Tomas, valid questions. To make it "as simple as possible" in the first version I think one code is redeemed once and for the full value. But agree, that is a valid point and I like the idea of being able to "split" it over multiple clouds.

Totally get that you would like to limit the amount of usage per user, we do that today as well for all customers coming our way, passport, public signups ... no difference. But I think that we need to agree upon a minim level that at the same time give the user "a good experience with openstack".'}, {'account_id': 13587, 'date': '2018-09-03 16:31:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)

My 2 cents Tobias :)'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2020-07-30 20:03:21.000000000', 'content': 'Removed reviewer Mohammed Naser with the following votes:

* Code-Review+1 by Mohammed Naser <mnaser@vexxhost.com>
'}]

commit_message:
[NetApp] Fix default ipspace deletion issue

The NetApp driver is fixed to avoid the deletion of cluster
ipspaces when deleting a share server. Now the share server
deletion skip ipspace removal if the ipspace is one of the
following: Cluster or Default.

Change-Id: I24cda6be69ef9258c6c637be48be32b93d835e0a
Closes-Bug: #1880747
(cherry picked from commit dbe34c08e2278eb472bc2cbf7f086d6deff7cab2)
(cherry picked from commit 2fe7452b1bf8b8975dcd663db3ecce98b5fb499c)
(cherry picked from commit bf97dcc9d4918ef4ae871ea96886a89a01ac9989)
(cherry picked from commit cfdb200e6bd798ce6fd5682567c006b56762ac7c)

commit_message:
Harden LVM driver deletion paths

During maintenance, administrators may decide
to unmount shares, snapshots or remove them
entirely prior to cleaning up LVM share resources
in manila. The driver should not fail on deletion
of missing resources.

Change-Id: Ieaf37ec10db9a8bdce6bb195b76335fea9b2b52f
Closes-Bug: #1888915
Signed-off-by: Goutham Pacha Ravi <gouthampravi@gmail.com>
(cherry picked from commit e57809fd74186714aec7dae305380a51c31fc7d5)
(cherry picked from commit 8620f7efed1c2b669a06f13440add1eb20ef12e9)
(cherry picked from commit 4e292ea884ff72341c2ab6733745fe6d35733aa8)

commit_message:
Update LVM volume extend

- do *not* skip fsck when extending
- have extend resize the filesystem itself
  rather than making a separate execution
  of ``resize2fs``

Due to an issue with Gerrit, we're unable
to preserve the Change-ID for this change.
The change-id in stable/ussuri and in the
main branch is I67ac549e790322c56d02db4424ec01a5449e6633

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-07-07 18:13:09.000000000', 'message': 'Fix rekeying volume with legacy encryption provider

Update volume_utils.check_encryption_provider() so it translates
a legacy provider class in the encryption dict it returns. For
example, if the volume's encryption metadata specifies
"nova.volume.encryptors.luks.LuksEncryptor" for the provider,
the function will a dict with "luks" as the provider.

Closes-Bug: #1886689
Change-Id: I172dab1641207849fdd6a9848ac7573cba236a8b
'}]
commit_message:
Fix rekeying volume with legacy encryption provider

Update volume_utils.check_encryption_provider() so it translates
a legacy provider class in the encryption dict it returns. For
example, if the volume's encryption metadata specifies
"nova.volume.encryptors.luks.LuksEncryptor" for the provider,
the function will a dict with "luks" as the provider.

Closes-Bug: #1886689
Change-Id: I172dab1641207849fdd6a9848ac7573cba236a8b

commit_message:
allow to specify drivername for postgres db

in newer versions of sqlalchemy a drivername is required to
avoid a warning. For postgres the driver is psycopg2.
The driver is optional.

Change-Id: Iffc84d224fd9891261d787241687991fd97f48f7

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-07-22 13:57:11.000000000', 'message': 'Remove /var/lib/config-data context task

The task should not be needed since we set the context in
openstack-selinux:

https://github.com/redhat-openstack/openstack-selinux/blob/master/local_settings.sh.in#L89
fcontext -N -$1 -t container_file_t \"$LOCALSTATEDIR/lib/config-data(/.*)?\"

This task is very expensive at scale and we should avoid these king of
things.

svirt_sandbox_file_t is an alias to container_file_t, so let's use
container_file_t directly to be consistent and not creating confusion.

This patch shouldn't be backported to Train because in Train we'll have
this task not removed but moved to run only under FFU context.

Change-Id: I973a49aec1a263e2a1ec3e5199803c86d6f77b35
Closes-Bug: #1887721
(cherry picked from commit 5864167034a20d20d38cd7f513b1319579765538)

commit_message:
Remove /var/lib/config-data context task

The task should not be needed since we set the context in
openstack-selinux:

https://github.com/redhat-openstack/openstack-selinux/blob/master/local_settings.sh.in#L89
fcontext -N -$1 -t container_file_t \"$LOCALSTATEDIR/lib/config-data(/.*)?\"

This task is very expensive at scale and we should avoid these king of
things.

svirt_sandbox_file_t is an alias to container_file_t, so let's use
container_file_t directly to be consistent and not creating confusion.

This patch shouldn't be backported to Train because in Train we'll have
this task not removed but moved to run only under FFU context.

Change-Id: I973a49aec1a263e2a1ec3e5199803c86d6f77b35
Closes-Bug: #1887721
(cherry picked from commit 5864167034a20d20d38cd7f513b1319579765538)

commit_message:
Avoid openvswitch restarts during re-run

For offload configuration on the first time, opevswitch
need to be restarted after the interface configured to
switchdev mode to enable VF-LAG. But once it is configured,
openvswitch should not be restarted, which will create
VF-LAG failures. In general, in the TripleO during
updates/upgrades, ovs restart will not be triggered
and it will be allowed to the user to restart or reboot
the node. Aligning with it, opevswitch restart has been
avoided on all os-net-config re-runs.
Closes-Bug: #1887957

Change-Id: I0a3b374b321ba039c8e0b1c126ac3eb59e6dc980
(cherry picked from commit 4c95f7d08732d8e4f4b865e8c119dee87b8196eb)

This fixes the following error from CI:

commit_message:
Adding description for testcases - identity part5

When Tempest is used in customer site, often we are required to
provide a testcase list including testcase names and descriptions.
Now no this kind of doc is available, so we can add descriptions
with the format of doc string for every testcase, so later we
can generata such a testcase description list.

There are hundreds of testcases missing descriptions, so we can
add them gradually, and limit the modified files in one patch
for the convenience of reviewing.

Change-Id: I47fc64ac84b4d0ea3da0a9469efec7bd6e0b0f3d
partially-implements: blueprint testcase-description

commit_message:
[ovn]: port forwarding -- documentation

This is a subset of the changes for implementing the floating IP
port forwarding feature in neutron, using OVN as the backend.

This changeset covers the documentation updates for the feature,
as well as a high-level description of how OVN implements it.

Partially-implements: ovn/port_forwarding
Partially-implements: blueprint portforwarding-description
Partial-Bug: #1877447

Change-Id: I2059a011f650dd7070a74dc6107aab2b15ca7104

commit_message:
Adding description for testcases - compute part5

When Tempest is used in customer site, often we are required to
provide a testcase list including testcase names and descriptions.
Now no this kind of doc is available, so we can add descriptions
with the format of doc string for every testcase, so later we
can generata such a testcase description list.

There are hundreds of testcases missing descriptions, so we can
add them gradually, and limit the modified files in one patch
for the convenience of reviewing.

Change-Id: I20744e4957fbd5b039fdd52ac530f11ac6d72319
partially-implements: blueprint testcase-description

commit_message:
Removes pre-commit hooks from Lucas-C

Removing pre-commit hooks from https://github.com/Lucas-C/pre-commit-hooks

For now, we're going to proceed with pre-commit and pycqa orgs
as they are considered as trusted repositories.

commit_message:
[ci] Remove explicit compression of log files

Compression is not needed post [1], explicit
compression renders them non-browsable.

This commit applies to legacy style jobs that
will soon be replaced with zuulv3 native jobs;
however, fixing it isn't terrible, and we
can use this fix for stable branches
where zuulv3 native jobs may not come for a
while.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-January/011875.html
Co-Authored-By: yatinkarel <ykarel@redhat.com>

Change-Id: Icd4f9dc435a807f6f729e4eb2d4df4b282ec79ac
Signed-off-by: Goutham Pacha Ravi <gouthampravi@gmail.com>
(cherry picked from commit 770e57ff3192c3828b2d3162ae1f132d3858997b)
(cherry picked from commit 531e810526843a6c152543396394068dd9873ad6)
(cherry picked from commit afb63e9db8dc470ee93f8532061fdafd19a7c93a)
(cherry picked from commit 2b16184da884820d579f02eff0910054e4041170)

subject: Undo the eventlet monkey patch for the privileged daemon
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 6928, 'name': 'Ben Nemec', 'email': 'openstack@nemebean.com', 'username': 'bnemec'}, {'_account_id': 11904, 'name': 'Sean McGinnis', 'email': 'sean.mcginnis@gmail.com', 'username': 'SeanM'}, {'_account_id': 15334, 'name': 'Stephen Finucane', 'display_name': 'stephenfin', 'email': 'stephenfin@redhat.com', 'username': 'sfinucan'}, {'_account_id': 16688, 'name': 'Rodolfo Alonso', 'email': 'ralonsoh@redhat.com', 'username': 'rodolfo-alonso-hernandez'}, {'_account_id': 21798, 'name': 'Bernard Cafarelli', 'email': 'bcafarel@redhat.com', 'username': 'bcafarel'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 28522, 'name': 'Hervé Beraud', 'email': 'herveberaud.pro@gmail.com', 'username': 'hberaud'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 16688, 'date': '2020-07-14 14:12:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 16688, 'date': '2020-07-14 16:59:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Published edit on patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 16688, 'date': '2020-07-14 17:01:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hello fellow reviewers. Please, if you have any question about this patch or the bug itself, do not hesitate to ask me (ralonsoh).

I think this patch will solve the problem we currently have in the Neutron CI, where fullstack and functional tests most of the times fail because of a timeout inside a privsep context execution.'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2020-07-14 18:06:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

Okay, I think I'm okay with this (more on that below), but -1 because it's a significant change in behavior and we need a release note for it. Also a bit of cleanup of eventlet compatibility code that should probably be done.

I'm a little surprised this is even needed. Apparently monkey patching survives over the fork? Since the daemon doesn't monkey patch itself, I wouldn't have expected that after we start a new process. I guess this is not necessary for the rootwrap case because it starts the daemon using subprocess, which apparently calls os.exec under the covers. Since that completely wipes out the previous process, there's no way for the monkey patching to persist.

The other thing I'm struggling with is to remember what the desired behavior here was. Since we don't explicitly monkey patch in the daemon, I'm forced to assume we intended it to run with native threads. We do have eventlet compatibility code too though[0]. I guess that's safe to remove with this change?

So this is tricky (like everything in privsep... ;-). I would love to have input from other reviewers given my uncertainty about what was the intended behavior here. However, given what I've found so far I'm +1 on the patch in general, modulo the things I mentioned at the start of this epic comment.

0: https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.privsep/src/commit/071ab480076ac8bf476d1beb51aec84612d2d703/oslo_privsep/daemon.py#L221"}, {'account_id': 16688, 'date': '2020-07-15 10:08:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> Okay, I think I'm okay with this (more on that below), but -1
 > because it's a significant change in behavior and we need a release
 > note for it. Also a bit of cleanup of eventlet compatibility code
 > that should probably be done.
 > 
 > I'm a little surprised this is even needed. Apparently monkey
 > patching survives over the fork? Since the daemon doesn't monkey
 > patch itself, I wouldn't have expected that after we start a new
 > process. I guess this is not necessary for the rootwrap case
 > because it starts the daemon using subprocess, which apparently
 > calls os.exec under the covers. Since that completely wipes out the
 > previous process, there's no way for the monkey patching to
 > persist.
 > 
 > The other thing I'm struggling with is to remember what the desired
 > behavior here was. Since we don't explicitly monkey patch in the
 > daemon, I'm forced to assume we intended it to run with native
 > threads. We do have eventlet compatibility code too though[0]. I
 > guess that's safe to remove with this change?
 > 
 > So this is tricky (like everything in privsep... ;-). I would love
 > to have input from other reviewers given my uncertainty about what
 > was the intended behavior here. However, given what I've found so
 > far I'm +1 on the patch in general, modulo the things I mentioned
 > at the start of this epic comment.
 > 
 > 0: https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.privsep/src/commit/071ab480076ac8bf476d1beb51aec84612d2d703/oslo_privsep/daemon.py#L221

Thanks for the review. I was looking for this kind of analysis, to check if what I'm proposing makes sense.

1) Code cleanup.
I need to bump the evenlet min version to handle the issue with min constrains. I know I'm using private methods, but this is the only way to retrieve those libraries patched by evenlet. Of course I can check if those methods exist first. I'll implement some UTs that will validate the current code; if any of those methods is changed, the UTs will fail.

2) Monkey patch survives fork.
I was surprised too, but here is the proof: http://paste.openstack.org/show/795936/
IMO, not only there is no need to monkey_patch the daemon, but this is introducing the error reported

3) The compatibility code in [0]
This code is used in the logger, that is used in the client side. IMO, that makes sense.

Again, thanks for the review and any other review is always welcome."}, {'account_id': 16688, 'date': '2020-07-15 11:26:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

testing patch: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/741017/'}, {'account_id': 16688, 'date': '2020-07-15 12:47:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 16688, 'date': '2020-07-15 14:48:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2020-07-17 09:42:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Hello,

I'm a bit nervous about these changes, I don't have a great experience with oslo.privsep and I don't know how it should works and the intended behavior, but by example, on oslo.messaging and oslo.utils patches have been submitted few years ago to handle timeout issues in monkey patched environments, so I'm afraid this kind of these changes could interfer with these one [1][2].

Many libraries or services, now expect to seen the stdlib has been monkey patched, by example on futurist [3], on oslo.service, and on openstack services too, so I suppose by doing this we could trigger unexpected side effects.

I can imagine 2 possible alternatives to these changes:
    1. continue with these changes but make them optional to mostly avoid side effect outside of neutron, with that others services will continue to use a monkey patched daemon.
    2. undo the monkey patch on the neutron side and lets oslo.privsep as it is.

Thoughts?

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/389739
[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/386656
[3] https://github.com/openstack/futurist/blob/master/futurist/_green.py#L31,L60"}, {'account_id': 16688, 'date': '2020-07-17 14:27:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> Hello,
 > 
 > I'm a bit nervous about these changes, I don't have a great
 > experience with oslo.privsep and I don't know how it should works
 > and the intended behavior, but by example, on oslo.messaging and
 > oslo.utils patches have been submitted few years ago to handle
 > timeout issues in monkey patched environments, so I'm afraid this
 > kind of these changes could interfer with these one [1][2].
 > 
 > Many libraries or services, now expect to seen the stdlib has been
 > monkey patched, by example on futurist [3], on oslo.service, and on
 > openstack services too, so I suppose by doing this we could trigger
 > unexpected side effects.
 > 
 > I can imagine 2 possible alternatives to these changes:
 > 1. continue with these changes but make them optional to mostly
 > avoid side effect outside of neutron, with that others services
 > will continue to use a monkey patched daemon.
 > 2. undo the monkey patch on the neutron side and lets oslo.privsep
 > as it is.
 > 
 > Thoughts?
 > 
 > [1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/389739
 > [2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/386656
 > [3] https://github.com/openstack/futurist/blob/master/futurist/_green.py#L31,L60


Hi Herve:

I have the same qualms. But as Ben confirmed, it was never the intention of having a daemon monkey patched running. Actually I'm more concerned (that's why opened the bug hehehe) in the other way around: running a patched daemon.

Those calls should be short lived method executions in root mode, an improved replacement of rootwrap. In other words, the is not intended to run long execution methods.

If the daemon is monkey patched and one of those calls execute a sleep (or any other method that returns the executor), who is in charge of returning the execution to this user thread? That's the problem I'm trying to solve here.

About the patches.
[1] is specifically a utility library for eventlet. That should be called only when eventlet is used: http://codesearch.openstack.org/?q=from%20oslo_utils%20import%20eventletutils&i=nope&files=&repos=

* https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.service/src/branch/master/oslo_service/loopingcall.py: used for things like hearbeats, should be never used in a short-lived task
* https://opendev.org/openstack/mistral/src/branch/master/mistral/rpc/kombu/kombu_server.py: this is an RPC server that should be never executed inside a privsep context.
* any use in oslo.messaging: related to server-client operations, same comment here

[2] I don't want to be rude, but I would have never accepted this patch. This is mixing threading with eventlet. That's incorrect. If the libraries are patched, everything pointing to threading should point to the corresponding eventlet implementations. That's the goal of monkey_patch, to translate those libraries/classes/methods to eventlet.
Anyway, same comment here: this is part of the rabbitmq code, specifically the heartbeat. That will never be executed in a privsep context.

[3] Again, it doesn't make sense (maybe I'm wrong). There is a eventlet method to now if a module is patched or not "is_monkey_patched(module)". Importing the library is not enough to know if the running process is monkey_patched or not.'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2020-07-17 16:22:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2

Thanks for your answers and point of view, you convinced me.

 > called only when eventlet is used: http://codesearch.openstack.org/?q=from%20oslo_utils%20import%20eventletutils&i=nope&files=&repos=

 > * https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.service/src/branch/master/oslo_service/loopingcall.py:
 > used for things like hearbeats, should be never used in a

 > this is an RPC server that should be never executed inside a
 > privsep context.
 > * any use in oslo.messaging: related to server-client operations,
 > same comment here
 > 
 > [2] I don't want to be rude, but I would have never accepted this
 > patch. This is mixing threading with eventlet. That's incorrect. If
 > the libraries are patched, everything pointing to threading should
 > point to the corresponding eventlet implementations. That's the
 > goal of monkey_patch, to translate those libraries/classes/methods

 > Anyway, same comment here: this is part of the rabbitmq code,

Ok I seen

 > eventlet method to now if a module is patched or not
 > "is_monkey_patched(module)". Importing the library is not enough to

I agree, `is_monkey_patched` should be prefered.'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2020-07-30 16:11:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

> [2] I don't want to be rude, but I would have never accepted this

 > point to the corresponding eventlet implementations. That's the
 > goal of monkey_patch, to translate those libraries/classes/methods
 > to eventlet.
 > Anyway, same comment here: this is part of the rabbitmq code,
 > specifically the heartbeat. That will never be executed in a
 > privsep context.
 
Trust me, we are in complete agreement on how horrible that is. That's why it was added as optional behavior. However, we looked into every other option available and none of them fixed the bug.

This patch brings consistency to the daemon so that it doesn't matter whether it was started by rootwrap or forking, so I think it's the right thing to do. Let's get it in and have the rest of the cycle to tease out any possible issues that arise from it."}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2020-07-30 16:12:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

commit_message:
Make run-local.yml use ansible_connection local, not ssh

If the intent of run-local.yml is to use a local ansible
connection and not an SSH ansible connection, as implied
by the tests/hosts.ini, then it shouldn't set a fact to
set ansible_connection to 'ssh'. This patch changes it to
'local'.

Change-Id: I7494a937749a434f9bfb2e14c47b36aebdf89664
Closes-Bug: #1864649
(cherry picked from commit 5f0c07943eeb2c655f147be5e59b5128775ec34a)

commit_message:
tripleo_states: change wording

Change the wording to replace "This or these node(s) failed to deploy"
by "The following node(s) had failures:"; failures can happen at a
different level (not necessarily deploy). Update the wording to avoid
any confusion.

Change-Id: I80041738df05dbe0da678efa91e861390ad4657e
Related-Bug: #1889212
(cherry picked from commit f1969830e095401040be66bf245d91d20a08b221)

commit_message:
tripleo_podman_purge: try to use -f when pruning images

Recent version of podman requires yes/no when pruning images, except if
-f is given as an argument.

Let's first try the new way, and fallback on the old method.

Change-Id: Ie2a70d4ec40c2a2142b0857822edd5122b63c941
Closes-Bug: #1889418
(cherry picked from commit f9b89173307bd6e8495c757c098c3dda01f8c822)

commit_message:
Speed up container builds

Turns out upgrading pip enables grpcio PyPi package to use wheels to
install binaries, avioding need to compile it every time. This saves a
ton of time when building containers.

Change-Id: I6e4a5f9fddd24b8e88c62b444e8b305ade3f7f2a

commit_message:
Unset public_endpoint by default

When public_endpoint is set but different urls are used for endpoints
(especially for admin endpoint and public endpoint), it can cause
problem with self-url detection in keystone because it always assumes
that the url should be directed to that public_endpoint even when
a request comes from admin endpoint.

This patch makes public_endpoint unset by default to avoid issues in
the deployment where admin endpoint and public endpoint are still
separated.

Related-bug: #1889017
Change-Id: Ia43e9dcd8085bbb0954b64873504398a85771032

subject: Switch 55-heat-config to async
messages: [{'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2020-07-29 15:14:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2020-07-30 12:53:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-07-29 15:14:32.000000000', 'message': "Switch 55-heat-config to async

If while a task is executing the ssh connection is severed, ansible will
automagically rerun the command under the covers. This causes problems
for long running 55-heat-config tasks as first process may have written
out the deployed json but not the notify.json that we use use to
determine if it was successful or not. This can lead to a failure
because the process either never runs to completion.  This change
switches the execution to always be run async to ensure that ssh
interruptions won't cause inconsistent failures.

We previously saw a similar issue when invoking the NetworkDeployments
using this process. We've moved the network configurations to the
NetworkConfig task in THT/common/deploy-steps.j2 but this code is still
used to invoked with OS::Heat::SoftwareDeploymentGroup

Change-Id: Ic911bb6d999caf2dc4afd4cff3d44047c03dc8e4
Related-Bug: #1792343
Closes-Bug: #1887846
(cherry picked from commit 43aaaaa1190d7f5e808c906e82abcf116e0508c9)
"}]
commit_message:
Switch 55-heat-config to async

If while a task is executing the ssh connection is severed, ansible will
automagically rerun the command under the covers. This causes problems
for long running 55-heat-config tasks as first process may have written
out the deployed json but not the notify.json that we use use to
determine if it was successful or not. This can lead to a failure
because the process either never runs to completion.  This change
switches the execution to always be run async to ensure that ssh
interruptions won't cause inconsistent failures.

We previously saw a similar issue when invoking the NetworkDeployments
using this process. We've moved the network configurations to the
NetworkConfig task in THT/common/deploy-steps.j2 but this code is still
used to invoked with OS::Heat::SoftwareDeploymentGroup

Change-Id: Ic911bb6d999caf2dc4afd4cff3d44047c03dc8e4
Related-Bug: #1792343
Closes-Bug: #1887846
(cherry picked from commit 43aaaaa1190d7f5e808c906e82abcf116e0508c9)

commit_message:
Do not manage healthcheck for nova-compute anymore

Since we're using native podman healthcheck, we don't need to manage the
systemd service anymore.

Closes-Bug: #1889221

Change-Id: Id5d693b6111f5906a99ffe4fec4befffc3940e23
(cherry picked from commit 2b718135294b8d97a6114670b051690b2ea0c1a0)

commit_message:
Add delegate_to in skiplist tasks

The skiplist requires python module from openstack-tempest-skiplist
available in the python path. This works when quickstart is being
executed from the undercloud, but in some systems where quickstart is
executed in a different host, it fails. Use delegate_to ensure it
will be executed from the host quickstart is being executed.

Partial-Bug: #1888244

Change-Id: I433e39c212e4ab887b6ed0776715e344bfa404d7

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-07-27 11:08:34.000000000', 'message': "Fix management address lookup for metal hosts in some deployments

Git history indicates that when Nova runs on metal hosts its
address was identified via the management bridge and an IP lookup.
When the dynamic-address-fact was added this link was broken
and metal hosts have been using the fallback of ansible_host
defined in dynamic-address-fact

Note that originally the 'management_bridge' host var was relied
upon, but this change pulls this bridge from the
'container_networks.container_address.bridge'

Change-Id: I9aaca445d135b574753722d6b8de28e4f99c427b
(cherry picked from commit fc1b6f3bf69c360ff475e035a24a29c6791a8843)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix management address lookup for metal hosts in some deployments

Git history indicates that when Nova runs on metal hosts its
address was identified via the management bridge and an IP lookup.
When the dynamic-address-fact was added this link was broken
and metal hosts have been using the fallback of ansible_host
defined in dynamic-address-fact

Note that originally the 'management_bridge' host var was relied
upon, but this change pulls this bridge from the
'container_networks.container_address.bridge'

Change-Id: I9aaca445d135b574753722d6b8de28e4f99c427b
(cherry picked from commit fc1b6f3bf69c360ff475e035a24a29c6791a8843)

subject: Add NUMA affinity policy traits
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 4393, 'name': 'Dan Smith', 'email': 'dms@danplanet.com', 'username': 'danms'}, {'_account_id': 11564, 'name': 'Chris Dent', 'email': 'cdent@anticdent.org', 'username': 'chdent'}, {'_account_id': 11604, 'name': 'sean mooney', 'email': 'smooney@redhat.com', 'username': 'sean-k-mooney'}, {'_account_id': 14070, 'name': 'Eric Fried', 'email': 'openstack@fried.cc', 'username': 'efried'}, {'_account_id': 15334, 'name': 'Stephen Finucane', 'display_name': 'stephenfin', 'email': 'stephenfin@redhat.com', 'username': 'sfinucan'}, {'_account_id': 16688, 'name': 'Rodolfo Alonso', 'email': 'ralonsoh@redhat.com', 'username': 'rodolfo-alonso-hernandez'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]

Thanks i think this makes sense altogh we shoudl hold off on megeing this untill the feature that use it are approved in neutron/nova'}, {'account_id': 16688, 'date': '2020-07-08 14:41:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow-1

Sure, -W until the spec is approved.'}, {'account_id': 16688, 'date': '2020-07-28 10:48:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: -Workflow

Spec is merged: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/740011/

Let's go for it!"}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2020-07-28 13:40:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Help me understand which resource this trait would be applied to. A PCI device? Sean's comment [1] implies that these might be attributes of the compute, but I can't get my head around that.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/739961/1/os_traits/compute/net.py@42"}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2020-07-28 16:06:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

at the moment it would be applited to pci device
in the futrue it would be used for vGPUs or PMEM
potentially.

where those resouces woudl have the trait would depend on the virt_driver used and if it supported numa affintiy policies for a given resouce.

so i expect this trait to exist potentailly multiple localtion within the RP tree.

as sriov port are not currently modeled in plamcnet i would expect this to be added as a trait on the compute node root provider for now.

if we model pci device in the future i could see the trait moving to the pci device RP or vgpu or pmem device RPs to indicate what policies are supported for each resoucce type request respectively.

for numa aware vms i could see this remaining on the root rp.

does that make sense.

the reason that these traits are bing added is so that if i request strict numa affinity on a neutron port we land on a host that can acchive that.

at present numa affinity polices are only supported  for sriov device or pci passthough vai the alias so teh current numa toplogy filter does not enforce this constrat for regualar neutron port.

it mearly operates by enforcing numa affinity if numa aware vswitch is configured on the host but there is no way to disable that or force the vms to land on a host where numa aware vswitch is configured.

to day you have to use host aggreates to do that if you desire it.
said another way when usign the numa aware vswtich feature today
the numa affintiy fo the network backend is determined by what host you land on with no way to express a policy other than using host aggrates and flaovr extra_specs or image metadata.'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2020-07-28 16:07:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

we could technically enhance the numatopology filter to do this too bug usign traits with placment fells more inline with the direction we have been going.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2020-07-28 16:29:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

Thanks for the explanation, Sean. That makes sense to me.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2020-07-29 12:52:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

There's no context on why this is needed or what it's intended to solve. Could you add this to the commit message?

Later: I see Eric was also requesting this and Sean has answered below. It needs to go into the commit message though, IMO"}, {'account_id': 16688, 'date': '2020-07-29 13:00:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2020-07-29 13:08:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2

There was a time I got raked over the coals for requesting "how we're going to use this" -- but that was in the file comments, which (I agree) shouldn't be prescriptive. Fleshing out the commit message is totally legit :)'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2020-07-30 14:49:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 16688, 'date': '2020-07-30 14:52:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2020-07-30 15:04:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2020-07-30 15:46:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-2

Discussed this today on IRC [1]. To summarize what I took out of that conversation, these traits are intended for use of child resource providers (RPs), not necessarily the root (compute node) RP. The idea is that not all device types would have the ability to enforce a given NUMA affinity policy or even allow the NUMA affinity to be configurable, so you could have an SR-IOV device whose NUMA affinity with instance cores/memory is fully configurable and a PCI device that is not. However, I think the argument for this is pretty weak. In virtually all (all?) cases, we (nova) are the ones that choose to enforce this NUMA affinity, so if we wanted to make this configurable we'd just have to ratchet back the amount of work we're doing.

We're also hoping to start modeling NUMA in placement and I'm not sure how these traits would work in that world. In that world, enforcing strict affinity for e.g. a PCI device would not be done via a trait bur rather by ensuring the parent of the RP associated with this device was the one we would be consuming MEMORY_MB, DISK and VCPU/PCPU from. This obviously entails a whole lot of work wrt reporting things to placement.

Overall, it doesn't seem like this is necessary for now at least, hence the -2. We might want to add a trait to indicate the a compute node is able to process NUMA affinity policies on neutron ports, but I imagine that could be a binary "capability" trait, if it was even necessary.

[1] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-nova/%23openstack-nova.2020-07-30.log.html#t2020-07-30T14:47:53'}, {'account_id': 16688, 'date': '2020-07-30 15:47:21.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

OK, after a conversation in IRC [1], the port NUMA affinity information is going to be provided in a new extension.

This won't be needed for now.

[1]http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-nova/%23openstack-nova.2020-07-30.log.html#t2020-07-30T14:47:53"}]

commit_message:
Add NUMA affinity policy traits

These new traits correspond to the NUMA affinity policy described in
[1]. Any Neutron port, independently of the type, will be able to
contain one or none of these three new traits. That will define the
required NUMA affinity policy when scheduling a virtual machine with
this Neutron port.

[1]https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/queens/implemented/share-pci-between-numa-nodes.html

Change-Id: Id8d1d5da8eb7e1a3e52001c21eebf9c82eb80637
Related-Bug: #1886798

commit_message:
Deprecate ineffective ignore_default_tenant parameter

The keystone::resource::service_identity::ignore_default_tenant has
been ineffective in fact, since tenant parameters were removed from
keystone_user resource[1].
This patch deprecates that useless parameter.

[1] 8461e9acfbf7783e69489a4bdd6a24532bd4e33a

Change-Id: Id90dd6fc5c352f696ecea9a4a98c6b6ba04db3aa

commit_message:
Ensure virtualenv is installed.

As part of the cleanup test node python spec [1], the
pip and virtualenv elements were removed from the
infra image builds. Therefore, it's the zuul job itself
the one which needs to make sure virtualenv is installed.

This patch installs virtualenv using the generic zuul
role ensurei-virtualenv.

[1] - https://docs.opendev.org/opendev/infra-specs/latest/specs/cleanup-test-node-python.html

Change-Id: Id20ee6bf069f53739f7a5ea7983edf2fc9b445d2
