commit_message:
Remove any python3 package before UC leapp.

The Tobiko package installas python3-devel which enters in
conflict during the leapp upgrade procedure. This change removes any
python3 package before running leapp.

Change-Id: Id7cca3e4f819c2dfdb3947c8c3522d98d03b5a86

subject: Enforce that import methods are not enabled in pure WSGI mode
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 1004, 'name': 'Mohammed Naser', 'email': 'mnaser@vexxhost.com', 'username': 'mnaser'}, {'_account_id': 4393, 'name': 'Dan Smith', 'email': 'dms@danplanet.com', 'username': 'danms'}, {'_account_id': 5202, 'name': 'Erno Kuvaja', 'email': 'jokke@usr.fi', 'username': 'jokke'}, {'_account_id': 8556, 'name': 'Ghanshyam', 'display_name': 'Ghanshyam Mann', 'email': 'gmann@ghanshyammann.com', 'username': 'ghanshyam'}, {'_account_id': 9008, 'name': 'VMware NSX CI', 'username': 'vmwareminesweeper', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 9303, 'name': 'Abhishek Kekane', 'email': 'akekane@redhat.com', 'username': 'abhishekkekane'}, {'_account_id': 11904, 'name': 'Sean McGinnis', 'email': 'sean.mcginnis@gmail.com', 'username': 'SeanM'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2020-07-16 16:58:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2020-07-16 17:33:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2020-07-16 17:45:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Review-Priority+1

Thank you Dan!!'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2020-07-16 20:36:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Confirmed this works because devstack is currently leaving the default methods enabled:

 ERROR glance RuntimeError: enabled_import_methods must be empty when running as a pure WSGI app

Now I will depends-on the devstack patch to configure them off and it should pass.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2020-07-16 20:37:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2020-07-16 22:00:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

This now passes devstack. I *think* the reason this is not passing grenade is because we don't get a chance to disable the import methods in config during the upgrade because we're expected to work with the old config. Need to think on that a bit."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2020-07-17 16:42:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 5202, 'date': '2020-07-17 18:28:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-2

We really shouldn't be doing this. It was discussion when we made the Image Import being enabled by default for actually make it mandatory that at least one of the methods would be enabled but we decided to not do that for easier migration and unforeseen corner cases.

This will not fix any of the issues running Glance without eventlet and specially be counter intuitive indication when we move towards service tokens and image-upload being reserved to be used for that purpose only (namely for not needing Cinder and Nova to go through import)."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2020-07-17 18:43:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> We really shouldn't be doing this. It was discussion when we made
 > the Image Import being enabled by default for actually make it
 > mandatory that at least one of the methods would be enabled but we
 > decided to not do that for easier migration and unforeseen corner
 > cases.
 > 
 > This will not fix any of the issues running Glance without eventlet
 > and specially be counter intuitive indication when we move towards
 > service tokens and image-upload being reserved to be used for that
 > purpose only (namely for not needing Cinder and Nova to go through
 > import).

So, this came out of the need to write a tempest test. Tempest needs to run against any deployment without knowing its config (and without parameterizing everything). From that test, I can poke the info API, asking which methods are enabled, which by default is all of them, even in situations where we _know_ that they cannot be used. Even worse, the API client will be told "202: I'm working on this" and then nothing will ever happen, not even failure will be reported. That seems like exceedingly broken API behavior to me.

How can we write a reliable tempest test against Glance's API when it tells us things will work that can't possibly work?'}, {'account_id': 5202, 'date': '2020-07-20 16:46:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> So, this came out of the need to write a tempest test. Tempest
 > needs to run against any deployment without knowing its config (and
 > without parameterizing everything). From that test, I can poke the
 > info API, asking which methods are enabled, which by default is all
 > of them, even in situations where we _know_ that they cannot be
 > used. Even worse, the API client will be told "202: I'm working on
 > this" and then nothing will ever happen, not even failure will be
 > reported. That seems like exceedingly broken API behavior to me.
 > 
 > How can we write a reliable tempest test against Glance's API when
 > it tells us things will work that can't possibly work?

I have to admit that it has came to my mind as well every now and then getting around the issues with devstack/QA by detecting when we're deployed in the QA environment and making the glance-api behave differently. So far I still have enough integrity and some respect towards QA to not do that. If we take that route we might as well just drop those jobs off the check and gate.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2020-07-20 17:14:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> I have to admit that it has came to my mind as well every now and
 > then getting around the issues with devstack/QA by detecting when
 > we're deployed in the QA environment and making the glance-api
 > behave differently.

This isn't about QA and openstack CI. I can arrange the test skip lists in CI such that all the jobs will run with the proper config or skip the test, that's not the problem.

Tempest is used by lots of people in their own environment for validation. If I am an operator and don't want (or care) to have the import functionality work, I may very much prefer to run glance-api under uwsgi, like all the other API services. In that case, I would not be able to run tempest against my deployment without a failure, or long timeout unless the test itself can detect that a function is not enabled. You could argue that they should "just know" that they need to disable the methods before running the test, or that tempest should have a conf knob to disable that test. I obviously think that if we're running in pure WSGI mode and *know* that the import methods can't work, we should refuse to expose that they do.

Maybe you didn't see this, but devstack now deploys glance in standalone mode by default unless you *ask* for wsgi mode, separate from all the other services. So by default, import is testable in our CI.

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/741258/

 > So far I still have enough integrity and some
 > respect towards QA to not do that. If we take that route we might
 > as well just drop those jobs off the check and gate.

I'm missing something. Which jobs do you want to drop? Are you suggesting that glance stop supporting pure WSGI mode at all? If so, we should delete wsgi_app.py from the tree (or at least mark it as deprecated/unsupported).'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2020-07-20 17:19:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1

As an operator with multiple clouds, I think that we should _NOT_ start Glance if it's operating in a configuration that is not working.

While we love a unicorn world where everyone is using glance-api eventlet server and image import, that's just not the reality of things.  With a lot of deployments using mod_wsgi OR uwsgi (OSA).

Are we really blocking this on actual _user friendly behaviour_?"}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2020-07-20 18:03:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1

> > I have to admit that it has came to my mind as well every now and
 > > then getting around the issues with devstack/QA by detecting when
 > > we're deployed in the QA environment and making the glance-api
 > > behave differently.
 > 
 > This isn't about QA and openstack CI. I can arrange the test skip
 > lists in CI such that all the jobs will run with the proper config
 > or skip the test, that's not the problem.
 > 
 > Tempest is used by lots of people in their own environment for
 > validation. If I am an operator and don't want (or care) to have
 > the import functionality work, I may very much prefer to run
 > glance-api under uwsgi, like all the other API services. In that
 > case, I would not be able to run tempest against my deployment
 > without a failure, or long timeout unless the test itself can
 > detect that a function is not enabled. You could argue that they
 > should "just know" that they need to disable the methods before
 > running the test, or that tempest should have a conf knob to
 > disable that test. I obviously think that if we're running in pure
 > WSGI mode and *know* that the import methods can't work, we should
 > refuse to expose that they do.
 > 
 > Maybe you didn't see this, but devstack now deploys glance in
 > standalone mode by default unless you *ask* for wsgi mode, separate
 > from all the other services. So by default, import is testable in
 > our CI.
 > 
 > https://review.opendev.org/#/c/741258/
 > 
 > > So far I still have enough integrity and some
 > > respect towards QA to not do that. If we take that route we might
 > > as well just drop those jobs off the check and gate.
 > 
 > I'm missing something. Which jobs do you want to drop? Are you
 > suggesting that glance stop supporting pure WSGI mode at all? If
 > so, we should delete wsgi_app.py from the tree (or at least mark it
 > as deprecated/unsupported).

Yeah, we need to consider Tempest a very valid API user and /v2/info/import API should be reflecting the reality as much as it can. we know none of the import method work when glance in wsgi mode so returning failure makes this API more reliable. Also help operator to miss-configuration if they are in the impression that glance under wsgi with CONF.enabled_import_methods=True make import feature available for their users.

From Tempest perspective, as dan mentioned, API telling if import is ready to use or not is best way instead of adding feature flag. If glance did not have /v2/info/import API then yes we can add feature flag in tempest side.'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2020-07-20 18:09:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> > > I have to admit that it has came to my mind as well every now
 > and
 > > > then getting around the issues with devstack/QA by detecting
 > when
 > > > we're deployed in the QA environment and making the glance-api
 > > > behave differently.
 > >
 > > This isn't about QA and openstack CI. I can arrange the test skip
 > > lists in CI such that all the jobs will run with the proper
 > config
 > > or skip the test, that's not the problem.
 > >
 > > Tempest is used by lots of people in their own environment for
 > > validation. If I am an operator and don't want (or care) to have
 > > the import functionality work, I may very much prefer to run
 > > glance-api under uwsgi, like all the other API services. In that
 > > case, I would not be able to run tempest against my deployment
 > > without a failure, or long timeout unless the test itself can
 > > detect that a function is not enabled. You could argue that they
 > > should "just know" that they need to disable the methods before
 > > running the test, or that tempest should have a conf knob to
 > > disable that test. I obviously think that if we're running in
 > pure
 > > WSGI mode and *know* that the import methods can't work, we
 > should
 > > refuse to expose that they do.
 > >
 > > Maybe you didn't see this, but devstack now deploys glance in
 > > standalone mode by default unless you *ask* for wsgi mode,
 > separate
 > > from all the other services. So by default, import is testable in
 > > our CI.
 > >
 > > https://review.opendev.org/#/c/741258/
 > >
 > > > So far I still have enough integrity and some
 > > > respect towards QA to not do that. If we take that route we
 > might
 > > > as well just drop those jobs off the check and gate.
 > >
 > > I'm missing something. Which jobs do you want to drop? Are you
 > > suggesting that glance stop supporting pure WSGI mode at all? If
 > > so, we should delete wsgi_app.py from the tree (or at least mark
 > it
 > > as deprecated/unsupported).
 > 
 > Yeah, we need to consider Tempest a very valid API user and
 > /v2/info/import API should be reflecting the reality as much as it
 > can. we know none of the import method work when glance in wsgi
 > mode so returning failure makes this API more reliable. Also help
 > operator to miss-configuration if they are in the impression that
 > glance under wsgi with CONF.enabled_import_methods=True make import
 > feature available for their users.
 > 
 > From Tempest perspective, as dan mentioned, API telling if import
 > is ready to use or not is best way instead of adding feature flag.
 > If glance did not have /v2/info/import API then yes we can add
 > feature flag in tempest side.

s/CONF.enabled_import_methods=True/CONF.enabled_import_methods=['glance-direct', 'web-download', 'copy-image']

or default value of CONF.enabled_import'}, {'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2020-07-20 18:12:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Somehow I agree with erno's concern that uwsgi with glance has many issues with uwsgi since its introduction and there were no constructive efforts taken to resolve those issues.

But as we are making progress by introducing new import workflow, import plugins, multiple stores support we should also make sure that we have enough CI jobs, tempest etc to verify this work.

IMHO, if we are not supporting running under uwsgi then we should remove this support from glance forever unless someone is interested in fixing it."}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2020-07-20 18:14:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2020-07-20 18:15:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

grenade job should be green with latest 741675'}, {'account_id': 5202, 'date': '2020-07-20 18:23:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> I'm missing something. Which jobs do you want to drop? Are you
 > suggesting that glance stop supporting pure WSGI mode at all? If
 > so, we should delete wsgi_app.py from the tree (or at least mark it
 > as deprecated/unsupported).

Removing it to avoid confusion would be the optimal approach. It's been unsupported from the very first release it was in due to the fact that it was broken and no-one wanted to fix it."}, {'account_id': 5202, 'date': '2020-07-20 18:31:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> As an operator with multiple clouds, I think that we should _NOT_
 > start Glance if it's operating in a configuration that is not
 > working.
 > 
 > While we love a unicorn world where everyone is using glance-api
 > eventlet server and image import, that's just not the reality of
 > things.  With a lot of deployments using mod_wsgi OR uwsgi (OSA).
 > 
 > Are we really blocking this on actual _user friendly behaviour_?

I'm more than happy to follow up on this request as soon as our CI is not relying it anymore. We've tried to get there for ~3 years now and as Dan pointed out it looks like we're finally getting there. Babysteps"}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2020-07-20 19:09:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

This actually seems like a reasonable approach to me.

The wsgi mode with glance is still a dumpster fire, but at least this helps prevent some badness, while allowing some operation if things are not configured in a way we know it is bad.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2020-07-21 00:43:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2020-07-30 15:34:24.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

This is moot now.'}]

commit_message:
Enforce that import methods are not enabled in pure WSGI mode

We know that glance cannot run async tasks when running in pure WSGI
mode. This means import cannot work, and we should not advertise via
the API that it can. This patch adds a check to the pure-WSGI init_app()
method to refuse to start if enabled_import_methods is not empty.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/741507
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/741675
Change-Id: Id1f761dccb5760a2a56fa78e737440b0588e81e6

commit_message:
Don't check openvswitch service if package isn't installed.

A follow up on I8c116aba50cc7f1cb7cd3fd32cf8aec868e074ec. Basically
don't try to enable openvswitch if it is not present.

Change-Id: I7b16f409cceb1c41ceedf8dfdae6ffd06ec59410
Closes-Bug: #1875743

subject: Performance: use import_tasks for check-containers.yml
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-07-30 09:09:24.000000000', 'message': 'Performance: use import_tasks for check-containers.yml

Including tasks has a performance penalty when compared with importing
tasks. If the include has a condition associated with it, then the
overhead of the include may be lower than the overhead of skipping all
imported tasks. In the case of the check-containers.yml include, the
included file only has a single task, so the overhead of skipping this
task will not be greater than the overhead of the task import. It
therefore makes sense to switch to use import_tasks there.

Partially-Implements: blueprint performance-improvements

Change-Id: I65d911670649960708b9f6a4c110d1a7df1ad8f7
(cherry picked from commit 9702d4c3c3f4abad671f48b97d82280a2ae32a71)
'}]
commit_message:
Performance: use import_tasks for check-containers.yml

Including tasks has a performance penalty when compared with importing
tasks. If the include has a condition associated with it, then the
overhead of the include may be lower than the overhead of skipping all
imported tasks. In the case of the check-containers.yml include, the
included file only has a single task, so the overhead of skipping this
task will not be greater than the overhead of the task import. It
therefore makes sense to switch to use import_tasks there.

Partially-Implements: blueprint performance-improvements

Change-Id: I65d911670649960708b9f6a4c110d1a7df1ad8f7
(cherry picked from commit 9702d4c3c3f4abad671f48b97d82280a2ae32a71)

commit_message:
fix(registry): corrects glance registry ingress

This corrects an issue with glance registry ingress failing due to a
name mismatch. This also provides a proper glance registry public secret that was
missing.

Change-Id: Ibe3d5ca774365b7f4df01940884953fc0181394f
Signed-off-by: Tin Lam <tin@irrational.io>

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-05-05 11:08:25.000000000', 'message': "Add subnet deleted handler

With [0] neutron introduced a mechanism to lock subnets and avoid
deletion of used subnets (see [1] for the bug details). As a side effect
this caused that after subnet deletion dhcp ports was not deleted as
no trigger arrived to call handle_port_update_event.

TODO: check if PRECOMMIT_DELETE_ASSOCIATIONS can be used instead to
avoid introduction of new methods (first check gave me terrible jurnal
exceptions, but let's have a better look)

[0] https://review.opendev.org/713045
[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1865891

Change-Id: I3aed8031c1b784c16dd7055afd41456ed935b7fc
Related-Bug: #1865891
Closes-Bug: #1876033

2) fix pep8 issues which mostly come from new version of isort
Fix pep8 job  and small fixes for functional jobs
New versions of isort broke pylint. This patch fixes it at 4.3.21.
The issue appeared on stable branches that functional jobs can't find
correct pip version and failed due to not actual neutron version.
Add mock to functional requirements.txt to make sure that neutron has it
in functional envrionment.
(cherry picked from commit d0a1d1c25eb90be4a2bed85de6c56b5fdf2d76d6)

Change-Id: I3aed8031c1b784c16dd7055afd41456ed935b7fc

commit_message:
This change is a squash of 2 different patches to pass the gate

1) Backport of subnet deleted handler
With [0] neutron introduced a mechanism to lock subnets and avoid
deletion of used subnets (see [1] for the bug details). As a side effect
this caused that after subnet deletion dhcp ports was not deleted as
no trigger arrived to call handle_port_update_event.
[0] https://review.opendev.org/713045
[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1865891
(cherry picked from commit ef420a935d042e47b21d5fa7a2e3cf048b2935ad)
Related-Bug: #1865891
Closes-Bug: #1876033

2) fix pep8 issues which mostly come from new version of isort
Fix pep8 job  and small fixes for functional jobs
New versions of isort broke pylint. This patch fixes it at 4.3.21.
The issue appeared on stable branches that functional jobs can't find
correct pip version and failed due to not actual neutron version.
Add mock to functional requirements.txt to make sure that neutron has it
in functional envrionment.
(cherry picked from commit e4367d791702c3e40a3796dd753b58546599cef8)

Change-Id: I3aed8031c1b784c16dd7055afd41456ed935b7fc

commit_message:
[NetApp] update set_preferred_dc for ontapi 1.150

ONTAP 9.5 adds vserver cifs domain preferred-dc configuration
validation. The parameter 'skip-config-validation' is mandatory
for 'cifs-domain-preferred-dc-add' now and is set to false,
i.e. an invalid config will raise early.

Change-Id: I5eb97ba1b29ad24b296e12064f81eb93533c6b99
Closes-Bug: 1887643
(cherry picked from commit 3057d0643e8a93c4ae857159d96e94541ad0be4d)
(cherry picked from commit 7248532de8927c953a6d32491060b11b1e4f2a6b)
(cherry picked from commit 6ad361a1858e9b349e3b379e720ff95bd38ac7ff)

commit_message:
Add example for role specific parameters

How to define and use a role specific parameter with a different
variable name. A service can have a more specific name whereas the
role variable has a more generic name.

Working example based on: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/738925/

Change-Id: I1eb291d36483f138a523b3dc9a3b8a9a1baf581a
Signed-off-by: Luke Short <ekultails@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Add default selinux mount options for cinder nfs

When using cinder-nfs selinux mount options must be provided when selinux
is enabled. This change will ensure that the cinder-nfs setup mimics
our glance-nfs setup, and ensures our default configuration will work
out of the box in a production environment.

Change-Id: I76ec002fddc8ade9d3c7c3d0f19f04d721cfb64e
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>

'}, {'created': '2020-07-23 06:29:37.000000000', 'message': 'Fix up upgrade coordination around authkey

Preamble: RHEL/CentOS 8 use pcs 0.10 which manages
/etc/pacemaker/authkey for all remotes and core cluster nodes.

commit_message:
Fix up upgrade coordination around authkey

Preamble: RHEL/CentOS 8 use pcs 0.10 which manages
/etc/pacemaker/authkey for all remotes and core cluster nodes.
That was not the case with pcs 0.9 where we had to manage that file
on our own.

This patch does three things:
1) It introduces a force_authkey parameter so we can use the existing
   authkey file even when pcs 0.10 is being used
2) It introduces a parameter called force_oldstyle to forcibly create remotes in
   the pcs 0.9 way (which is different than the pcs 0.10 way)
3) On remotes it makes sure that any resource is ordered *after* the
   pcsd/pacemaker_remote service

1) and 2) are needed to be able to run puppet when the core cluster is
on RHEL/CentOS 8 whereas the remotes are on RHEL/CentOS 7. In this
situation we need to keep using the authkey we manage on both remotes
and core cluster nodes *and* we need to be creating the remotes in the
old pcs 0.9 way.

Tested this with multiple IHA FFU runs and also on a plain non-IHA Train
deployment with this change.

Related-Bug: #1888398

Change-Id: I0c551c2d8a856e49acd4f25794591d84ca8641d6

commit_message:
container-images: add librados2 to gnocchi-base

This package is needed so the right dependencies are installed in the
gnocchi base container images and db_sync can run fine when ceph is
used as a backend.


Partial-Bug: #1889192
Change-Id: Ic0bfdec756a23460f9257e78c508d167d21f0792
(cherry picked from commit c6e680e180f457b8b9085d503ea8e8b6ccdad90d)

messages: [{'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2020-07-28 21:47:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2020-07-28 23:06:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2020-07-29 02:36:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 8833, 'date': '2020-07-30 05:07:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:\n\nrecheck'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-07-28 21:47:08.000000000', 'message': "Fix parameter_defaults for nova less deploy

We seem to be using incorrect parameters for HostnameFormat and
Count when generating environment for nova less deploy.

It's always {{role.name}}Count and {{role.name}}HostnameFormat

(adapted from tripleo-ansible commit d958b45ebbc986e8381a540f69508e8f91f13081)

Change-Id: Ied6dbd349924db58f6323b878b8ee2e070d8719f
"}]
commit_message:
Fix parameter_defaults for nova less deploy

We seem to be using incorrect parameters for HostnameFormat and
Count when generating environment for nova less deploy.

It's always {{role.name}}Count and {{role.name}}HostnameFormat

(adapted from tripleo-ansible commit d958b45ebbc986e8381a540f69508e8f91f13081)

Change-Id: Ied6dbd349924db58f6323b878b8ee2e070d8719f

'}, {'created': '2020-07-23 06:10:53.000000000', 'message': 'Do not create stonith location constraint when there is a single node

This is needed for IHA FFU. And the reason is as follows:
When we upgrade the first node of the control plane (in the 3 controller
case scenario), we create a brand new one-node cluster. Now when the
stonith location constraint for ipmi is created, it assigns a negative
score to the ipmi resource running on the single node and so it will
simply be stopped and not run at all. This creates a problem at the
end of the upgrade process for the first controller, because
the final steps that verify resources are up will fail:
  fatal: [controller-0]: FAILED! => {"changed": false, "error": "Error: waiting timeout\n\nPending actions:\n\tAction 29:
  stonith-fence_ipmilan-525400c4f1c1_monitor_0\ton cont roller-0\n\tAction 28: stonith-controller-0-on\ton controller-0\nError performing
  operation: Timer expired\n", "msg": "Failed, to set the resource openstack-cinder-volume to the state enable", "output": "", "rc": 1}

That is because pacemaker will calculate a transition that requires a
stonith 'ON' operation which cannot happen because the stonith
resource is not running.
I've checked with Beekhof and this is a bit of a current limitation
in pacemaker when running on a single node (inability to ignore the
negative score when there is only one node). To avoid this we
only create the stonith location constraint when there is more than
one node (as output by crm_node -l)

Related-Bug: #1888398
Change-Id: Iefe68c26b188922d1e8fe4cd0d24242262ee6665

negative score when there is only one node). To avoid this we
only create the stonith location constraint when there is more than

commit_message:
Do not create stonith location constraint when there is a single node

This is needed for IHA FFU. And the reason is as follows:
When we upgrade the first node of the control plane (in the 3 controller
case scenario), we create a brand new one-node cluster. Now when the
stonith location constraint for ipmi is created, it assigns a negative
score to the ipmi resource running on the single node and so it will
simply be stopped and not run at all. This creates a problem at the
end of the upgrade process for the first controller, because
the final steps that verify resources are up will fail:
  fatal: [controller-0]: FAILED! => {"changed": false, "error": "Error: waiting timeout\n\nPending actions:\n\tAction 29:
  stonith-fence_ipmilan-525400c4f1c1_monitor_0\ton cont roller-0\n\tAction 28: stonith-controller-0-on\ton controller-0\nError performing
  operation: Timer expired\n", "msg": "Failed, to set the resource openstack-cinder-volume to the state enable", "output": "", "rc": 1}

That is because pacemaker will calculate a transition that requires a
stonith 'ON' operation which cannot happen because the stonith
resource is not running.
I've checked with Beekhof and this is a bit of a current limitation
in pacemaker when running on a single node (inability to ignore the
negative score when there is only one node). To avoid this we
only create the stonith location constraint when there is more than
one node (as output by crm_node -l)

Tested a number of times on IHA FFU successfully.

Related-Bug: #1888398
Change-Id: Iefe68c26b188922d1e8fe4cd0d24242262ee6665

subject: Retry calling backup_cib()
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 8297, 'name': 'Sofer Athlan-Guyot', 'email': 'sathlang@redhat.com', 'username': 'chem'}, {'_account_id': 11090, 'name': 'Sergii Golovatiuk', 'email': 'sgolovat@redhat.com', 'username': 'holser'}, {'_account_id': 11166, 'name': 'Lukas Bezdicka', 'email': 'social@v3.sk', 'username': 'xbezdick'}, {'_account_id': 20778, 'name': 'Damien Ciabrini', 'email': 'dciabrin@redhat.com', 'username': 'dciabrin'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 26343, 'name': 'Jose Luis Franco', 'email': 'jfrancoa@redhat.com', 'username': 'jfrancoa'}]

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-07-21 08:16:01.000000000', 'message': "WIP Retry backup_cib()

Currently if backup_cib() fails we just give up instantly.
In most cases this is actually okay since there are no chances
that the command succeeds in later retries. There are a number of cases
though were retrying should be done. IHA FFU is one of them because the
following might happen:
Jul 21 04:59:45 compute-1 puppet-user[61009]: Debug: Executing: '/sbin/ip6tables-save'
Jul 21 04:59:46 compute-1 pacemaker-remoted[42459]: warning: Cannot proxy IPC connection from uid 0 gid 0 to cib_rw because not connected to cluster
Jul 21 04:59:46 compute-1 pacemaker-remoted[42459]: error: Error in connection setup (/dev/shm/qb-42459-61225-14-DzDuCR/qb): Remote I/O error (121)
Jul 21 04:59:46 compute-1 puppet-user[61009]: Error: /Stage[main]/Tripleo::Profile::Pacemaker::Compute_instanceha/Pacemaker::Property[compute-instanceha-role-node-property]/Pcmk_property[property-compute-1-compute-instanceha-role]: Could not evaluate: backup_cib: Running: pcs cluster cib /var/lib/pacemaker/cib/puppet-cib-backup20200721-61008-hz2sdw failed with code: 1 -> Error: unable to get cib

And only later we get:
Jul 21 05:01:22 compute-1 pacemaker-remoted[42459]: notice: Remote client connection accepted

That is due to the fact that we cannot necessarily control at what point
the core cluster retries the connection, so we should strive for
retrying a few times no matter what

Change-Id: I1b5c2ed35f83b6572db9e919a4af4cd46f0e98e8

"}, {'created': '2020-07-23 06:17:43.000000000', 'message': "Retry calling backup_cib()

Currently if backup_cib() fails we just give up instantly.
In most cases this is actually okay since there are no chances
that the command succeeds in later retries. There are a number of cases
though were retrying should be done. IHA FFU is one of them because the
following might happen:
1) On the compute node we will try to set up a property when the remote
   is not yet connected
Jul 21 04:59:45 compute-1 puppet-user[61009]: Debug: Executing: '/sbin/ip6tables-save'
Jul 21 04:59:46 compute-1 pacemaker-remoted[42459]: warning: Cannot proxy IPC connection from uid 0 gid 0 to cib_rw because not connected to cluster
Jul 21 04:59:46 compute-1 pacemaker-remoted[42459]: error: Error in connection setup (/dev/shm/qb-42459-61225-14-DzDuCR/qb): Remote I/O error (121)
Jul 21 04:59:46 compute-1 puppet-user[61009]: Error: /Stage[main]/Tripleo::Profile::Pacemaker::Compute_instanceha/Pacemaker::Property[compute-instanceha-role-node-property]/Pcmk_property[property-compute-1-compute-instanceha-role]: Could not evaluate: backup_cib: Running: pcs cluster cib /var/lib/pacemaker/cib/puppet-cib-backup20200721-61008-hz2sdw failed with code: 1 -> Error: unable to get cib

2) This happens because in IHA FFU after the control plane has been
   upgraded we upgrade the compute nodes one by one, without running
   any other commands on the control plane. So we need to keep retrying
   setting the property even if backup_cib() fails because eventually
   the core cluster *will* reconnect to the remote:
Jul 21 05:01:22 compute-1 pacemaker-remoted[42459]: notice: Remote client connection accepted

That is due to the fact that we cannot necessarily control at what point
the core cluster retries the connection, so we should strive for
retrying a few times no matter what.

Tested this 4 times in a row successfully (before this patch we would
fail quite often)

Related-Bug: #1888398

Change-Id: I1b5c2ed35f83b6572db9e919a4af4cd46f0e98e8
"}]
commit_message:
Retry calling backup_cib()

Currently if backup_cib() fails we just give up instantly.
In most cases this is actually okay since there are no chances
that the command succeeds in later retries. There are a number of cases
though were retrying should be done. IHA FFU is one of them because the
following might happen:
1) On the compute node we will try to set up a property when the remote
   is not yet connected
Jul 21 04:59:45 compute-1 puppet-user[61009]: Debug: Executing: '/sbin/ip6tables-save'
Jul 21 04:59:46 compute-1 pacemaker-remoted[42459]: warning: Cannot proxy IPC connection from uid 0 gid 0 to cib_rw because not connected to cluster
Jul 21 04:59:46 compute-1 pacemaker-remoted[42459]: error: Error in connection setup (/dev/shm/qb-42459-61225-14-DzDuCR/qb): Remote I/O error (121)
Jul 21 04:59:46 compute-1 puppet-user[61009]: Error: /Stage[main]/Tripleo::Profile::Pacemaker::Compute_instanceha/Pacemaker::Property[compute-instanceha-role-node-property]/Pcmk_property[property-compute-1-compute-instanceha-role]: Could not evaluate: backup_cib: Running: pcs cluster cib /var/lib/pacemaker/cib/puppet-cib-backup20200721-61008-hz2sdw failed with code: 1 -> Error: unable to get cib

2) This happens because in IHA FFU after the control plane has been
   upgraded we upgrade the compute nodes one by one, without running
   any other commands on the control plane. So we need to keep retrying
   setting the property even if backup_cib() fails because eventually
   the core cluster *will* reconnect to the remote:
Jul 21 05:01:22 compute-1 pacemaker-remoted[42459]: notice: Remote client connection accepted

That is due to the fact that we cannot necessarily control at what point
the core cluster retries the connection, so we should strive for
retrying a few times no matter what.

Tested this 4 times in a row successfully (before this patch we would
fail quite often)

Related-Bug: #1888398

Change-Id: I1b5c2ed35f83b6572db9e919a4af4cd46f0e98e8

commit_message:
Fix KeyError exc in volumes_client

is_resource_deleted method of v3 volumes_client was wrongly accessing
id value of a volume causing KeyError - in case the being deleted
volume was in error_deleting state.

Closes-Bug: #1887980
Change-Id: I6cea9917c248ceaa8b7cd60d0a20a2bf7540d9b9

subject: Replace "Member" with "member"
messages: [{'account_id': 24824, 'date': '2020-06-23 19:32:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 9545, 'date': '2020-07-30 12:20:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-06-23 19:32:17.000000000', 'message': 'Replace "Member" with "member"

The default Keystone bootstrap process adds "member" (lowercase "m"),
not "Member".
https://docs.openstack.org/keystone/latest/admin/case-insensitive.html#roles

Tempest was changed to have a lowercase default:
https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/99d4dae684
https://bugs.launchpad.net/tempest/+bug/1330132

This change does the same for rally-openstack.

Change-Id: I2b9877ac02d0d41927ff69c56e0812aa0cbbac94
Closes-Bug: #1884825
'}]
commit_message:
Replace "Member" with "member"

The default Keystone bootstrap process adds "member" (lowercase "m"),
not "Member".
https://docs.openstack.org/keystone/latest/admin/case-insensitive.html#roles

Tempest was changed to have a lowercase default:
https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/99d4dae684
https://bugs.launchpad.net/tempest/+bug/1330132

This change does the same for rally-openstack.

Change-Id: I2b9877ac02d0d41927ff69c56e0812aa0cbbac94
Closes-Bug: #1884825

commit_message:
Update LVM volume extend

- do *not* skip fsck when extending
- have extend resize the filesystem itself
  rather than making a separate execution
  of ``resize2fs``

Due to an issue with Gerrit, we're unable
to preserve the Change-ID for this change.
The change-id in stable/ussuri and in the
main branch is I67ac549e790322c56d02db4424ec01a5449e6633

Closes-bug: #1887694
Change-Id: Ieebd69ec9671d48f2d9de0ae3e110518cba4f6f9
(cherry picked from commit c94e1deff1bde93d4167ceeb9dafc494d12cd60c)
(cherry picked from commit 2a3c18edcd9c4f7def293f18a6cac286ec00bc49)
(cherry picked from commit 2063c93c078c990f4865994dc0221662cbc4c5d5)
(cherry picked from commit e378f44598a9a2560f35948e108bc03f2bbb0adb)

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-07-28 19:11:15.000000000', 'message': "[ci] Remove explicit compression of log files

Compression is not needed post [1], explicit
compression renders them non-browsable.

This commit applies to legacy style jobs that
will soon be replaced with zuulv3 native jobs;
however, fixing it isn't terrible, and we
can use this fix for stable branches
where zuulv3 native jobs may not come for a
while.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-January/011875.html
Co-Authored-By: yatinkarel <ykarel@redhat.com>

Change-Id: Icd4f9dc435a807f6f729e4eb2d4df4b282ec79ac
Signed-off-by: Goutham Pacha Ravi <gouthampravi@gmail.com>
(cherry picked from commit 770e57ff3192c3828b2d3162ae1f132d3858997b)
(cherry picked from commit 531e810526843a6c152543396394068dd9873ad6)
(cherry picked from commit afb63e9db8dc470ee93f8532061fdafd19a7c93a)
"}]
commit_message:
[ci] Remove explicit compression of log files

Compression is not needed post [1], explicit
compression renders them non-browsable.

This commit applies to legacy style jobs that
will soon be replaced with zuulv3 native jobs;
however, fixing it isn't terrible, and we
can use this fix for stable branches
where zuulv3 native jobs may not come for a
while.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-January/011875.html
Co-Authored-By: yatinkarel <ykarel@redhat.com>

Change-Id: Icd4f9dc435a807f6f729e4eb2d4df4b282ec79ac
Signed-off-by: Goutham Pacha Ravi <gouthampravi@gmail.com>
(cherry picked from commit 770e57ff3192c3828b2d3162ae1f132d3858997b)
(cherry picked from commit 531e810526843a6c152543396394068dd9873ad6)
(cherry picked from commit afb63e9db8dc470ee93f8532061fdafd19a7c93a)

commit_message:
Close session objects in container_image.py

We don't seem to close the request session objects we create,
after using them and this results in unclosed sockets and
the warning.

ResourceWarning: unclosed <socket.socket fd=17...

Change-Id: Ida92643820e04563cc5ea75788a07d73955efe9e
(cherry picked from commit b407f78a8467130fc239e797d28a131ee9bcce65)

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-07-23 13:28:18.000000000', 'message': "Use plugin instead of devstack service for Neutron.

In our devstack local.conf samples we are using invocation for enabling
Neutron like:

enable_service neutron

which shouldn't be used, in favor of:

enable_plugin neutron https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron

For some strange reason, first invocation results in failing of create
the stack with enabled Neutron metadata service, which is needed for
kuryr tempest test to be run properly.

Change-Id: I3cd8e2a46e65e65195d4ee17e973980baf83618d
"}, {'created': '2020-07-24 04:06:50.000000000', 'message': "Use plugin instead of devstack service for Neutron.

In our devstack local.conf samples we are using invocation for enabling
Neutron like:

enable_service neutron

which shouldn't be used, in favor of:

enable_plugin neutron https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron

For some strange reason, first invocation results in failing of create
the stack with enabled Neutron metadata service, which is needed for
kuryr tempest test to be run properly.

Depends-On: If639b63dcf660ed709623c8d5f788026619c895c
Change-Id: I3cd8e2a46e65e65195d4ee17e973980baf83618d
"}]
commit_message:
Use plugin instead of devstack service for Neutron.

In our devstack local.conf samples we are using invocation for enabling
Neutron like:

enable_service neutron

which shouldn't be used, in favor of:

enable_plugin neutron https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron

For some strange reason, first invocation results in failing of create
the stack with enabled Neutron metadata service, which is needed for
kuryr tempest test to be run properly.

Depends-On: If639b63dcf660ed709623c8d5f788026619c895c
Change-Id: I3cd8e2a46e65e65195d4ee17e973980baf83618d

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-09-25 19:40:49.000000000', 'message': "Add dns_domain support to OS::Neutron::ProviderNet

It is actually possible to set OS::Neutron::Net-dns_domain but
not OS::Neutron::ProviderNet-dns_domain with heat.   Since this
is allowed using python-neutronclient, there're no reasons to
not allow this using heat.

Change-Id: I5b085e469f3fd24c797d5dcaf39dbe56f6ad5cdf
closes-bug: #36808
"}, {'created': '2019-09-25 20:51:12.000000000', 'message': "Add dns_domain support to OS::Neutron::ProviderNet

It is actually possible to set OS::Neutron::Net-dns_domain but
not OS::Neutron::ProviderNet-dns_domain with heat.   Since this

commit_message:
Add dns_domain support to OS::Neutron::ProviderNet

It is actually possible to set OS::Neutron::Net-dns_domain but
not OS::Neutron::ProviderNet-dns_domain with heat.   Since this
is allowed using python-neutronclient, there're no reasons to
not allow this using heat.

Change-Id: I5b085e469f3fd24c797d5dcaf39dbe56f6ad5cdf
Task: 36808

commit_message:
Set 'DEBUG' to horizon::log_level if HorizonDebug or Debug is true

Previously, if HorzionDebug of Debug was true, horizon::django_debug
was set to True. However, those parameters didn't change the logger
level of horizon components. By this change, when HorizonDebug or
Debug is True, horizon::log_level is set to 'DEBUG'.

Change-Id: I0a140682c552ba8a4e943124330852259e66142d

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-06-02 18:28:08.000000000', 'message': "Stop to use the __future__ module.

The __future__ module [1] was used in this context to ensure compatibility
between python 2 and python 3.

We previously dropped the support of python 2.7 [2] and now we only support
python 3 so we don't need to continue to use this module and the imports
listed below.

Imports commonly used and their related PEPs:
- `division` is related to PEP 238 [3]
- `print_function` is related to PEP 3105 [4]
- `unicode_literals` is related to PEP 3112 [5]
- `with_statement` is related to PEP 343 [6]
- `absolute_import` is related to PEP 328 [7]

[1] https://docs.python.org/3/library/__future__.html
[2] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html
[3] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0238
[4] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-3105
[5] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-3112
[6] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0343
[7] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0328

Change-Id: Ic4f42591f8d877c1f8e797e351031ae861959076
"}]
commit_message:
Stop to use the __future__ module.

The __future__ module [1] was used in this context to ensure compatibility
between python 2 and python 3.

We previously dropped the support of python 2.7 [2] and now we only support
python 3 so we don't need to continue to use this module and the imports
listed below.

Imports commonly used and their related PEPs:
- `division` is related to PEP 238 [3]
- `print_function` is related to PEP 3105 [4]
- `unicode_literals` is related to PEP 3112 [5]
- `with_statement` is related to PEP 343 [6]
- `absolute_import` is related to PEP 328 [7]

[1] https://docs.python.org/3/library/__future__.html
[2] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html
[3] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0238
[4] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-3105
[5] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-3112
[6] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0343
[7] https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0328

Change-Id: Ic4f42591f8d877c1f8e797e351031ae861959076

commit_message:
[k8s] Fix PreDeletionFailed if Heat stack is missing

When a stack has already been deleted, the pre-deletion tries to check
for loadbalancer for stack_id=None which returns PreDeletionFailed
exception. This patch addresses this issue.

Change-Id: Id7a9c5080633bca411398b7989026004e74ccb65
Story: 2007657
Task: 39783
(cherry picked from commit f5d32eb51ce91ff3cda52f7b52e733263a02ad3d)

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-06-26 11:09:13.000000000', 'message': "Fix ServerAddressOutputMapping for private clusters

Following changes were introduced in Train release:

- Allow setting network, subnet and FIP when creating cluster
  (I11579ff6b83d133c71c2cbf49ee4b20996dfb918)
- ng-7: Adapt parameter and output mappings
  (I45cf765977c7f5a92f28ae12c469b98435763163)

The first change allowed setting cluster.floating_ip_enabled but the
second change introduced ServerAddressOutputMapping conditional on
cluster_template.floating_ip_enabled which leads to an edge case where
if floating_ip_enabled is overriden to False when a cluster is created
when it is True in the cluster_template scope, we see this error in the
conductor logs: ValueError: Field `node_addresses[0]' cannot be None and
the cluster remains forever stuck in CREATE_IN_PROGRESS status despite
Heat reaching CREATE_COMPLETE. This commit addresses this issue by
correctly referring to the cluster.floating_ip_enabled.

Change-Id: Ic83f625178786d4750a66dd6dd6db35c05bc0272
Story: 2007550
Task: 39401
(cherry picked from commit 0e58e267d1eb0acd55d943e0abd208bf41377285)
"}, {'created': '2020-06-26 11:12:13.000000000', 'message': "Fix ServerAddressOutputMapping for private clusters

commit_message:
Fix ServerAddressOutputMapping for private clusters

Following changes were introduced in Train release:

- Allow setting network, subnet and FIP when creating cluster
  (I11579ff6b83d133c71c2cbf49ee4b20996dfb918)
- ng-7: Adapt parameter and output mappings
  (I45cf765977c7f5a92f28ae12c469b98435763163)

The first change allowed setting cluster.floating_ip_enabled but the
second change introduced ServerAddressOutputMapping conditional on
cluster_template.floating_ip_enabled which leads to an edge case where
if floating_ip_enabled is overriden to False when a cluster is created
when it is True in the cluster_template scope, we see this error in the
conductor logs: ValueError: Field `node_addresses[0]' cannot be None and
the cluster remains forever stuck in CREATE_IN_PROGRESS status despite
Heat reaching CREATE_COMPLETE. This commit addresses this issue by
correctly referring to the cluster.floating_ip_enabled.

Change-Id: Ic83f625178786d4750a66dd6dd6db35c05bc0272
Story: 2007550
Task: 39401
(cherry picked from commit 0e58e267d1eb0acd55d943e0abd208bf41377285)

subject: Fix label fixed_network_cidr
messages: [{'account_id': 28022, 'date': '2020-06-26 11:01:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 6484, 'date': '2020-07-15 03:04:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 6484, 'date': '2020-07-15 03:04:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 20498, 'date': '2020-07-30 11:46:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-06-26 11:01:54.000000000', 'message': "Fix label fixed_network_cidr

Now the label `fixed_network_cidr` is not handled correctly, no matter
if the label is set, the default value '10.0.0.0/24' is used for
fixed network anyway. This patch fixes it and renamed it as
`fixed_subnet_cidr` to make less confusion. The new behaviour will be:
1. If the label `fixed_subnet_cidr` is set but no fixed subnet passed
   in, then a new subnet will be created with the given CIDR.
2. If a fixed subnet is passed in by user, then label `fixed_subnet_cidr`
   will be override with the CIDR from the given subnet.

Task: 39847
Story: 2007712

Change-Id: Id05e36696bf85297a556fcd959ed897fe47b7354
(cherry picked from commit 001b9c61019841a4a8755118f45be02b69daf673)
"}, {'created': '2020-07-15 03:04:04.000000000', 'message': "Fix label fixed_network_cidr

Now the label `fixed_network_cidr` is not handled correctly, no matter
if the label is set, the default value '10.0.0.0/24' is used for
fixed network anyway. This patch fixes it and renamed it as
`fixed_subnet_cidr` to make less confusion. The new behaviour will be:
1. If the label `fixed_subnet_cidr` is set but no fixed subnet passed
   in, then a new subnet will be created with the given CIDR.
2. If a fixed subnet is passed in by user, then label `fixed_subnet_cidr`
   will be override with the CIDR from the given subnet.

Task: 39847
Story: 2007712

Change-Id: Id05e36696bf85297a556fcd959ed897fe47b7354
(cherry picked from commit 001b9c61019841a4a8755118f45be02b69daf673)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix label fixed_network_cidr

Now the label `fixed_network_cidr` is not handled correctly, no matter
if the label is set, the default value '10.0.0.0/24' is used for
fixed network anyway. This patch fixes it and renamed it as
`fixed_subnet_cidr` to make less confusion. The new behaviour will be:
1. If the label `fixed_subnet_cidr` is set but no fixed subnet passed
   in, then a new subnet will be created with the given CIDR.
2. If a fixed subnet is passed in by user, then label `fixed_subnet_cidr`
   will be override with the CIDR from the given subnet.

Task: 39847
Story: 2007712

Change-Id: Id05e36696bf85297a556fcd959ed897fe47b7354
(cherry picked from commit 001b9c61019841a4a8755118f45be02b69daf673)

[{'created': '2020-07-30 09:07:16.000000000', 'message': 'Performance: use import_tasks for check-containers.yml

Including tasks has a performance penalty when compared with importing
tasks. If the include has a condition associated with it, then the
overhead of the include may be lower than the overhead of skipping all
imported tasks. In the case of the check-containers.yml include, the

commit_message:
Performance: use import_tasks for check-containers.yml

Including tasks has a performance penalty when compared with importing
tasks. If the include has a condition associated with it, then the
overhead of the include may be lower than the overhead of skipping all
imported tasks. In the case of the check-containers.yml include, the
included file only has a single task, so the overhead of skipping this
task will not be greater than the overhead of the task import. It
therefore makes sense to switch to use import_tasks there.

Partially-Implements: blueprint performance-improvements

Change-Id: I65d911670649960708b9f6a4c110d1a7df1ad8f7
(cherry picked from commit 9702d4c3c3f4abad671f48b97d82280a2ae32a71)

commit_message:
tripleo_deploy: report failed deployment if exception was found

If an exception was found, mark the deployment as failed and not
successful like this was the case until now if some functions would fail
to run, e.g. wait_api_port_ready.

Change-Id: I91e41818be76da53d0a61b868f0559fee7e6a7e5
Closes-Bug: #1889394

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-06-18 15:46:46.000000000', 'message': 'rbd: Add breadcrumb for when udev rules are missing

Ceph uses udev rules [1] to create a '/dev/rbdN' ->
'/dev/rbd/{pool}/{device}' symlink. If these rules aren't correctly
configured (or entirely missing, say, when running nova-compute in a
container where udev won't be running), this symlink won't be created.
This causes things to crash and burn when locally attaching an encrypted
volume, at least:

  oslo_concurrency.processutils.ProcessExecutionError: Unexpected error while running command.
  Command: cryptsetup luksOpen --key-file=- /dev/rbd/volumes/volume-foo crypt-volume-foo
  Exit code: 4
  Stdout: ''
  Stderr: "Device /dev/rbd/volumes/foo doesn't exist or access denied.\n"

('foo' being a stand-in for a very long 'device-$UUID' name)

The solution to this involves making sure udev works properly, but for
now simply add some breadcrumbs to allow people diagnose the potential
issues.

[1] https://github.com/ceph/ceph/blob/v14.0.0/udev/50-rbd.rules

Change-Id: I2775f55039695c7ec029106c0dafe4d46255b336
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>
'}, {'created': '2020-06-18 17:41:04.000000000', 'message': 'rbd: Create symlink when udev is not present or configured

Ceph uses udev rules [1] to create a '/dev/rbd/{pool}/{device}' ->
'/dev/rbdN' symlink. In container-based deployments where the udev
daemon is not present, this symlink will never be created. This causes
things to crash and burn when locally attaching an encrypted volume:

  oslo_concurrency.processutils.ProcessExecutionError: Unexpected error while running command.
  Command: cryptsetup luksOpen --key-file=- /dev/rbd/volumes/volume-foo crypt-volume-foo
  Exit code: 4
  Stdout: ''
  Stderr: "Device /dev/rbd/volumes/foo doesn't exist or access denied.\n"

('foo' being a stand-in for a very long 'device-$UUID' name)

Rather than require udev be added to the container or ceph's udev rules
be placed on the host, simply do the work of the udev rule and create
the symlink manually.

Note that it is necessary to use this symlink rather than the original
block device. The LUKS encryptor overrides this symlink [2] in order to
enable transparent disk encryption. Attempting to use the block device
itself will result in a recursive symlink. We could modify that
behavior, but this is a much larger change.

[1] https://github.com/ceph/ceph/blob/v14.0.0/udev/50-rbd.rules
[2] https://github.com/openstack/os-brick/blob/3.1.0/os_brick/encryptors/luks.py#L191-L195

Change-Id: I2775f55039695c7ec029106c0dafe4d46255b336
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>
'}, {'created': '2020-06-18 17:55:28.000000000', 'message': 'rbd: Create symlink when udev is not present or configured

  Exit code: 4

Rather than require udev be added to the container or ceph's udev rules
be placed on the host, simply do the work of the udev rule and create
the symlink manually.

Note that it is necessary to use this symlink rather than the original

[1] https://github.com/ceph/ceph/blob/v14.0.0/udev/50-rbd.rules

Change-Id: I2775f55039695c7ec029106c0dafe4d46255b336
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>
Closes-Bug: #1884114
'}, {'created': '2020-07-22 10:19:28.000000000', 'message': 'rbd: Warn if ceph udev rules are not configured

The LUKS encryptor feature expects devices to have a symbolic link that
it can overwrite in order to enable transparent encryption/decryption
for instances [1]. This is generally the case for RBD volumes, as Ceph
uses udev rules [2] to create a '/dev/rbd/{pool}/{device}' ->
'/dev/rbdN' symlink. However, in an environment where udev daemon is not
present or configured correctly, this symlink will never be configured.
This causes things to crash and burn in a rather non-obvious manner when
locally attaching an encrypted RBD volume:

  oslo_concurrency.processutils.ProcessExecutionError: Unexpected error while running command.
  Command: cryptsetup luksOpen --key-file=- /dev/rbd/volumes/volume-foo crypt-volume-foo
  Exit code: 4
  Stdout: ''
  Stderr: "Device /dev/rbd/volumes/foo doesn't exist or access denied.\n"

('foo' being a stand-in for a very long 'device-$UUID' name)

The long term fix here is to probably stop relying on the side effects
of these udev rules, i.e. the symlinks, but that is a far more involved
fix that would not be backportable. Instead, for now we simply leave a
breadcrumb for the user, informing them as to what's gone wrong and
encouraging them to look at the bug report for more information.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/os-brick/blob/3.1.0/os_brick/encryptors/luks.py#L191-L195
[2] https://github.com/ceph/ceph/blob/v14.0.0/udev/50-rbd.rules

Change-Id: I2775f55039695c7ec029106c0dafe4d46255b336
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>
Related-Bug: #1884114

commit_message:
rbd: Warn if ceph udev rules are not configured

The LUKS encryptor feature expects devices to have a symbolic link that
it can overwrite in order to enable transparent encryption/decryption
for instances [1]. This is generally the case for RBD volumes, as Ceph
uses udev rules [2] to create a '/dev/rbd/{pool}/{device}' ->
'/dev/rbdN' symlink. However, in an environment where udev daemon is not
present or configured correctly, this symlink will never be configured.
This causes things to crash and burn in a rather non-obvious manner when
locally attaching an encrypted RBD volume:

  oslo_concurrency.processutils.ProcessExecutionError: Unexpected error while running command.
  Command: cryptsetup luksOpen --key-file=- /dev/rbd/volumes/volume-foo crypt-volume-foo
  Exit code: 4
  Stdout: ''
  Stderr: "Device /dev/rbd/volumes/foo doesn't exist or access denied.\n"

('foo' being a stand-in for a very long 'device-$UUID' name)

The long term fix here is to probably stop relying on the side effects
of these udev rules, i.e. the symlinks, but that is a far more involved
fix that would not be backportable. Instead, for now we simply leave a
breadcrumb for the user, informing them as to what's gone wrong and
encouraging them to look at the bug report for more information.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/os-brick/blob/3.1.0/os_brick/encryptors/luks.py#L191-L195
[2] https://github.com/ceph/ceph/blob/v14.0.0/udev/50-rbd.rules

Change-Id: I2775f55039695c7ec029106c0dafe4d46255b336
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>
Related-Bug: #1884114

There are two fixes included in this patch:

1. List nodes correctly. We have renamed minion to node, which
   cause the filter doesn't work correctly.
2. The response from magnumclient resize method is not a json,
   so we need to convert it to dict before return. Rolling upgrade
   has the same issue.

commit_message:
Fix cluster resize

There are two fixes included in this patch:

1. List nodes correctly. We have renamed minion to node, which
   cause the filter doesn't work correctly.
2. The response from magnumclient resize method is not a json,
   so we need to convert it to dict before return. Rolling upgrade
   has the same issue.

Task: 39810
Story: 2007697

Change-Id: I7a03dfea2c84a423f15cfbe4194a8492f72dbd35
(cherry picked from commit 96312eaf09dfec4424938a09d63a7190b2808d20)

commit_message:
Reset power state upon adoption failure

When adoption fails, we should back out the power state
so we don't accidently save a state that shouldn't be
preserved due to the failure.

Change-Id: I4647d0141fc639d49ccb0ef195577f18cd35bd30
Story: 2007901
Task: 40447

commit_message:
Adding description for testcases - compute part4

When Tempest is used in customer site, often we are required to
provide a testcase list including testcase names and descriptions.
Now no this kind of doc is available, so we can add descriptions
with the format of doc string for every testcase, so later we
can generata such a testcase description list.

There are hundreds of testcases missing descriptions, so we can
add them gradually, and limit the modified files in one patch
for the convenience of reviewing.

Change-Id: If14b4ec678355c850275ef38f9ed70cc0c877946
partially-implements: blueprint testcase-description

When looking through my IRC logs: I had a deployment problem using nspawn container and stable/stein release. The same change is already merged to the stable/stein branch and I just requested it for Train for upgrading purposes. The problem was, that Keystone API calls have been done from the deployment host and that was not able to find cloud "default". So there was some problem with the correct Python interpreter. As Python was changed to Python 3 for the Train release, the problem does not occur with Train.'}, {'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2020-07-29 14:42:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

commit_message:
Same service setup host python interpreter for LDAP domains

The service setup host python interpreter has been made configurable and
the same needs to be used to setup a Keystone LDAP domain.

Change-Id: Iacaa75b4bb077f25632ec0eecbdf5fd57bb959b2

commit_message:
Release sync for 20.08

- Classic charms: sync charm-helpers.
- Classic ceph based charms:  also sync charms.ceph
- Reactive charms: trigger a rebuild
- sync tox.ini
- sync requirements.txt and test-requirements.txt

Change-Id: Ib02fc1203d1e20f4cdc21a3a5e0bbdb7b590b182

commit_message:
Adding description for testcases - network part3

When Tempest is used in customer site, often we are required to
provide a testcase list including testcase names and descriptions.
Now no this kind of doc is available, so we can add descriptions
with the format of doc string for every testcase, so later we
can generata such a testcase description list.

There are hundreds of testcases missing descriptions, so we can
add them gradually, and limit the modified files in one patch
for the convenience of reviewing.

Change-Id: I5f4cd174a3dc2f23188b72ff856ec4e8f4b51414
partially-implements: blueprint testcase-description

Adding description for testcases - identity part3

When Tempest is used in customer site, often we are required to
provide a testcase list including testcase names and descriptions.
Now no this kind of doc is available, so we can add descriptions
with the format of doc string for every testcase, so later we
can generata such a testcase description list.

There are hundreds of testcases missing descriptions, so we can
add them gradually, and limit the modified files in one patch
for the convenience of reviewing.

Change-Id: I6d8fd63c7a473b498cde35ed53d83270b9e526c3
partially-implements: blueprint testcase-description

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-07-29 08:20:31.000000000', 'message': 'AgentRAID: Account for empty results in post-configuration checks

Currently we only raise if no results are returned at all. Due to a bug
apply_configuration is currently returning None, resulting in a TypeError
later on. This changes help catching such situations earlier.

Also provides a clearer error message that mentions RAID rather then
just generic "deploying" or "cleaning".

Change-Id: I5e047b6b0a00043594a93e87e09ee60b9342dbfa
'}]
commit_message:
AgentRAID: Account for empty results in post-configuration checks

Currently we only raise if no results are returned at all. Due to a bug
apply_configuration is currently returning None, resulting in a TypeError
later on. This changes help catching such situations earlier.

Also provides a clearer error message that mentions RAID rather then
just generic "deploying" or "cleaning".

Change-Id: I5e047b6b0a00043594a93e87e09ee60b9342dbfa

commit_message:
Performance: remove unnecessary conditions from includes

There are a number of tasks where we conditionally use include_tasks
with a condition, and the condition is always true. This change removes
these conditions, in preparation for switching unconditional task
includes to task imports.

Partially-Implements: blueprint performance-improvements

Change-Id: I3804c440fe3552950d9d434ef5409f685c39bbcf
(cherry picked from commit 7ff27de7acd573a4ae94a930ec040bd28060918c)

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-07-29 17:33:15.000000000', 'message': "Remove locks before RPC bus is started

A partner performing some testing recognized a case where if a request
is sent to the Ironic Conductor while it is in the process of starting,
and the request makes it into be processed, yet latter the operation
fails with errors such as NodeNotLocked exception. Notably they were
able to reproduce this by requesting the attachment or detachment of
a VIF at the same time as restarting the conductor.

In part, this condition is due to to the conductor being restarted
where the conductors table includes the node being restarted and
the webserver has not possibly had a chance to observe that the
conductor is in the process of restarting as the hash ring is
still valid.

In short - Incoming RPC requests can come in during the initialization
window and as such we should not remove locks while the conductor could
possibly already be receiving work.

As such, we've added a ``prepare_host`` method which initializes
the conductor database connection and removes the stale locks.
Under normal operating conditions, the database client is reused.

rhbz# 1847305

Change-Id: I8e759168f1dc81cdcf430f3e33be990731595ec3
(cherry picked from commit b8e4aba1ec06885c9b377d5ad659a13fea41049d)
"}]
commit_message:
Remove locks before RPC bus is started

A partner performing some testing recognized a case where if a request
is sent to the Ironic Conductor while it is in the process of starting,
and the request makes it into be processed, yet latter the operation
fails with errors such as NodeNotLocked exception. Notably they were
able to reproduce this by requesting the attachment or detachment of
a VIF at the same time as restarting the conductor.

In part, this condition is due to to the conductor being restarted
where the conductors table includes the node being restarted and
the webserver has not possibly had a chance to observe that the
conductor is in the process of restarting as the hash ring is
still valid.

In short - Incoming RPC requests can come in during the initialization
window and as such we should not remove locks while the conductor could
possibly already be receiving work.

As such, we've added a ``prepare_host`` method which initializes
the conductor database connection and removes the stale locks.
Under normal operating conditions, the database client is reused.

rhbz# 1847305

Change-Id: I8e759168f1dc81cdcf430f3e33be990731595ec3
(cherry picked from commit b8e4aba1ec06885c9b377d5ad659a13fea41049d)

subject: Allow to configure default TLDs
messages:
[{'account_id': 12356, 'date': '2020-07-27 13:10:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 13252, 'date': '2020-07-27 19:13:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2

I don't see why this should be necessary or useful, having this option would make the API behaviour depend on a config option that isn't discoverable for an API user. Creating TLDs is considered an admin feature, so once an admin decides to create any TLD list, they can also create their list of default TLDs, and that will resolve the issue.

We may be more careful in the tempest tests, though, like making sure they also work in an environment where there are predefined TLDs. Or maybe skip the corresponding tests in that case."}, {'account_id': 12356, 'date': '2020-07-30 10:35:58.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

makes sense to fix the tests instead, first attempt at https://review.opendev.org/743946'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-07-27 13:10:03.000000000', 'message': 'Allow to configure default TLDs

It might be useful to introduce a configuration option for some
TLDs, such as in-addr.arpa, so that they do not have to be created
explicitly.

Change-Id: Ie3caea276aa1d264445be83a9ad1c7ca88e0fee6
Closes-Bug: 1889073
'}]
commit_message:
Allow to configure default TLDs

It might be useful to introduce a configuration option for some
TLDs, such as in-addr.arpa, so that they do not have to be created
explicitly.

Change-Id: Ie3caea276aa1d264445be83a9ad1c7ca88e0fee6
Closes-Bug: 1889073

commit_message:
Performance: remove unnecessary conditions from includes

There are a number of tasks where we conditionally use include_tasks
with a condition, and the condition is always true. This change removes
these conditions, in preparation for switching unconditional task
includes to task imports.

Partially-Implements: blueprint performance-improvements

Change-Id: I3804c440fe3552950d9d434ef5409f685c39bbcf
(cherry picked from commit 7ff27de7acd573a4ae94a930ec040bd28060918c)

commit_message:
Performance: remove unnecessary conditions from includes

There are a number of tasks where we conditionally use include_tasks
with a condition, and the condition is always true. This change removes
these conditions, in preparation for switching unconditional task
includes to task imports.

Partially-Implements: blueprint performance-improvements

Change-Id: I3804c440fe3552950d9d434ef5409f685c39bbcf

commit_message:
[NetApp] Fix default ipspace deletion issue

The NetApp driver is fixed to avoid the deletion of cluster
ipspaces when deleting a share server. Now the share server
deletion skip ipspace removal if the ipspace is one of the
following: Cluster or Default.

Change-Id: I24cda6be69ef9258c6c637be48be32b93d835e0a
Closes-Bug: #1880747
(cherry picked from commit dbe34c08e2278eb472bc2cbf7f086d6deff7cab2)
(cherry picked from commit 2fe7452b1bf8b8975dcd663db3ecce98b5fb499c)
(cherry picked from commit bf97dcc9d4918ef4ae871ea96886a89a01ac9989)

[{'account_id': 24422, 'date': '2017-12-18 15:27:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 9555, 'date': '2017-12-18 16:09:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(6 comments)

I haven't looked at the tests yet, and there are some mechanical things at least which would need to be fixed.

However, I'm in favour of this approach. It does the following on rebuild:

* Create a new volume with the new image_id
* Delete the old volume (if terminate_on_delete)
* Update the root BDM to point to the new volume

Also, I'm pretty sure it should use the new cinder apis with attachment_id. It needs to be able to delete a legacy attachment, but it only needs to create the new one."}, {'account_id': 23498, 'date': '2017-12-18 16:14:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-12-18 15:27:48.000000000', 'message': 'Fix the problems that volume-backed server rebuild

If the instance was booted from volume, then rebuild will only change
the image, but the instance will still boot from the original volume.

To solve it,I judge from "root_bdm.is_volume" to know which style it boot from.
And if boot from volume,we can recreate_volume by the given image_href.On the
basis of image_href,so we can use the "image_meta" to create root volume.Lastly,
setting the new_root_bdm to "bdms".

Change-Id: I6e7b7011677aed702c42cf7865473f819bfc51dc
Co-Authored-By:Laszlo Hegedus <laszlo.hegedus@ericsson.com>
Closes-Bug: #1482040
Closes-Bug: #1378689
Closes-Bug: #1474253

commit_message:
Support volume-backed server rebuild

If the instance was booted from volume, then rebuild will only
change the image, but the instance will still boot from the
original volume.

To solve it,we judge from "root_bdm.is_volume" to know which style
it boot from.And if boot from volume,we can recreate_volume by the
given image_href.On the basis of image_href,so we can use the
"image_meta" to create a new root volume.Lastly,update the root BDM
to point to the new volume.

Now you can provide any format image to rebuild volume-backed server

Change-Id: I6e7b7011677aed702c42cf7865473f819bfc51dc
Co-Authored-By:Laszlo Hegedus <laszlo.hegedus@ericsson.com>
Implements: blueprint volume-backed-server-rebuild
Closes-Bug: #1378689

[{'created': '2020-07-28 13:57:33.000000000', 'message': "Install bindep packages when installing lib from src

Most libs maintain their own system packages in a local bindep.txt file.
We don't currently use those when installing packages from source, which
can result in broken package installs.

This adds a flag to always attempt to install bindep packages if the
bindep.txt file exists. If a file cannot be found, it will just emit a
warning and carry on.

Change-Id: Ia0570f837b8af1c3fee0a314b026a4a7ed27e6a9
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>
"}]
commit_message:
Install bindep packages when installing lib from src

Most libs maintain their own system packages in a local bindep.txt file.
We don't currently use those when installing packages from source, which
can result in broken package installs.

This adds a flag to always attempt to install bindep packages if the
bindep.txt file exists. If a file cannot be found, it will just emit a
warning and carry on.

Change-Id: Ia0570f837b8af1c3fee0a314b026a4a7ed27e6a9
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

[{'created': '2020-07-27 21:13:35.000000000', 'message': 'Switch from include to include_tasks.

Currently the main entry point to select the tasks use the deprecated
include tasks.  This leads to a lot of skipped tasks during the any
run.

If you run update you can see all ffwd upgrade tasks and upgrade tasks
being skipped.

This fix this by using include_tasks with the tag always.

Closes-Bug: #1889126
Change-Id: Ia3764e56b526834283ae46dafe0b94e8a6639c96
'}]
commit_message:
Switch from include to include_tasks.

Currently the main entry point to select the tasks use the deprecated
include tasks.  This leads to a lot of skipped tasks during the any
run.

If you run update you can see all ffwd upgrade tasks and upgrade tasks
being skipped.

This fix this by using include_tasks with the tag always.

Closes-Bug: #1889126
Change-Id: Ia3764e56b526834283ae46dafe0b94e8a6639c96

'}, {'created': '2020-01-14 12:55:48.000000000', 'message': 'Add ConsistencyGroup Exceptions in tempest

The exceptions ConsistencyGroupException and
ConsistencyGroupSnapshotException are required by
cinder-tempest-plugin[1][2] when the
CG or CG Snapshot fails to create and is in error state.

commit_message:
Add ConsistencyGroup Exceptions in tempest

The exceptions ConsistencyGroupException and
ConsistencyGroupSnapshotException are required by
cinder-tempest-plugin[1][2] when the
CG or CG Snapshot fails to create and is in error state.
These exceptions never existed as part of the original topic[3]
but failures are seen while running tests as reported in the bug.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/cinder-tempest-plugin/blob/master/cinder_tempest_plugin/services/consistencygroups_client.py#L140
[2] https://github.com/openstack/cinder-tempest-plugin/blob/master/cinder_tempest_plugin/services/consistencygroups_client.py#L172
[3] https://review.opendev.org/#/q/topic:cg-tests+(status:open+OR+status:merged)

Change-Id: I62e0ba556b884c94f6e8796a2e6f6d8083277fa4
Closes-Bug: #1858417

commit_message:
ovn migration: Support stack name

The heat stack name is variable. This patch adds a new environment
variable to support migrating stacks that are different name than
overcloud.

Change-Id: I6fd72bf83def28ae633d720b8495888cea3ac0a3
Signed-off-by: Jakub Libosvar <libosvar@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit afd63d0b36c664ca42cdda498c6b0478cf9774dd)

(14 comments)

Hm, besides minor issues listed inline I think there's one fundamental problem here. So I don't see how the VIF activation feedback loop would work in this case.

You see, currently it works like this:

1. Pod gets created.
2. kuryr-daemon gets CNI request, it waits to see annotation on the pod.
3. VIF is being assigned and annotated to the pod by controller. Controller keeps polling Neutron API for port to become active.
4. kuryr-daemon sees that and binds the correct VIF to the pod namespace and starts polling for VIF to become active.
5. neutron-agent sees that VIF got plugged somewhere, does its own plugging and sends info about it to neutron-svc.
6. neutron-svc marks VIF as active.
7. kuryr-controller sees the port as active, so it updates the annotation to reflect that.
8. kuryr-daemon sees updated annotation and assumes everything's completed. *Only then CNI is returned with pod network info.*
9. K8s got the response from CNI, so it starts displaying IP for the pod.

If I read this code correctly this version will just immediately return to CNI once pod's plugged, which _may_ be inconsistent with CNI spec, as the network might not be fully functional just yet."}, {'account_id': 13692, 'date': '2020-07-23 18:57:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16:

(11 comments)'}, {'account_id': 11600, 'date': '2020-07-24 08:01:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16:

commit_message:
Pod annotations to KuryrPort CRD.

Till now, we were using pod annotations to store information regarding
state of the associated VIFs to pod. This alone have its own issues and
it's prone to the inconsistency in case of controller failures.

In this patch we propose new CRD called KuryrPort for storage the
information about VIFs.

Depends-On: If639b63dcf660ed709623c8d5f788026619c895c
Change-Id: I1e76ea949120f819dcab6d07714522a576e426f2

subject: Prometheus plugin for container-based VNFs monitoring specs

Thanks for commenting, Simon Pasquier.
If you have any idea with this blueprint, please feel free to let me know :)'}, {'account_id': 18955, 'date': '2019-07-16 13:26:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 29: Code-Review-1

(7 comments)

Thanks Jaeweek for re-spawning this spec, and seems nice.

I have few open questions, kindly look into the same.

* The scope(and the information provided in spec also) of spec seems scattered. It will better if we can re-frame it and make it more specific. 

* Scope of prometheous plugin: 
Scope of plugin is not clear, is it only for generating configuration for Prometheus server(for file-based service discovery) , as in line#257? 

* Triggering alarm: How the Tacker get notified about alarm and who/how will handle it.

* Action: As with this integration, we are going to support Infrastructure/application/netwok monitoring. So in case any trigger/failure just respawning the VDU is seems meaningless until we not come with specific use cases. So IMO We needs more rework/brainstorming on action part. Although if you have plan to keep it separate from the scope of this spec, I am ok with that, please mention the same in spec.'}, {'account_id': 18955, 'date': '2019-07-16 13:30:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 29:

@Simon

 > Prometheus dev here. I've found this spec a bit by accident but if
 > you have specific questions about Prometheus, I'd be happy to help.

Glad to see your interest. Kindly help us by providing your feedback on spec and open questions as well."}, {'account_id': 27334, 'date': '2019-07-22 01:44:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 29:

(7 comments)

Prometheus plugin for container-based VNFs monitoring specs

Develop a Prometheous plugin in Tacker VNFM to monitor vm-based and
container-based VNFs.

Blueprint: prometheus-plugin

Clone the openstack/tacker-specs repo to your machine:

git clone https://opendev.org/openstack/tacker-specs

Go into the cloned project

cd tacker-specs

Check out the patchset:

git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tacker-specs refs/changes/16/540416/29 && git checkout FETCH_HEAD

Go into the specs directory and move things:

cd specs
mkdir train
mv rocky/prometheus-plugin.rst train/

Create a index.rst inside train/ with the following content:

====================
Tacker Train Specifications
====================

.. toctree::
   :glob:
   :maxdepth: 1

   *

Commit your changes and push for review:
git rm rocky/prometheus-plugin.rst
git add train/*.rst
git commit --amend
git review'}, {'account_id': 27334, 'date': '2019-07-31 02:37:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-07-21 12:48:31.000000000', 'message': 'Make sure failed containers get stopped by systemd

When the main PID (i.e., common) of a container is killed because of
some reasons, systemd won't execute ExecStop command.
Current podman doesn't detect this failure ang recognize that container
is still running and this causes failure when systemd tries to restart
the container.

This patch introduces ExecStopPost configuration into systemd unit
files so that stop operation is executed even when a container fails
because of killed main process. The stale container should be cleaned
up by ExecStopPost task before systemd tries to restart it.

Note that the similar change has been introcuded to "podman generate
systemd" command already[1].
[1] https://github.com/containers/libpod/commit/e5c3432944245a740ed443803c654dcc9c3757f0

Change-Id: Ie2cb3bb63138b70019f86b88066697e98e333669
Closes-Bug: #1884866
(cherry picked from commit b8f412d81cf3bbbb4b3d0a420d76e91a3c620799)
'}]
commit_message:
Make sure failed containers get stopped by systemd

When the main PID (i.e., common) of a container is killed because of
some reasons, systemd won't execute ExecStop command.
Current podman doesn't detect this failure ang recognize that container
is still running and this causes failure when systemd tries to restart
the container.

This patch introduces ExecStopPost configuration into systemd unit
files so that stop operation is executed even when a container fails
because of killed main process. The stale container should be cleaned
up by ExecStopPost task before systemd tries to restart it.

Note that the similar change has been introcuded to "podman generate
systemd" command already[1].
[1] https://github.com/containers/libpod/commit/e5c3432944245a740ed443803c654dcc9c3757f0

Change-Id: Ie2cb3bb63138b70019f86b88066697e98e333669
Closes-Bug: #1884866
(cherry picked from commit b8f412d81cf3bbbb4b3d0a420d76e91a3c620799)

commit_message:
Updated/corrected service_status

This patch updates service_status check, importing what was done in
oooq-extras back in 2019[1].

This will allow to actually ensure only tripleo related services are
checked.

The legacy Docker support is still here in order to allow checking on
older releases.

This patch also adds some fancy molecule testing.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/637729/

commit_message:
Retire networking-l2gw: remove zuul jobs

networking-l2gw is not a neutron stadium project, and not governed by
openstack, so it is time to move it to x/ namespace. As a first step
disable zuul jobs to avoid collisions when the new repository will be
created as x/networking-l2gw.

Conflicts: .zuul.yaml, on rocky there were no templates, and as the
main goal is to remove networking-l2gw-tempest-plugin those jobs are
removed.
Added bindep.txt to make sure that mysql and other things are in place.
Pike: remove tripleo centos jobs and add openstack-python-jobs-neutron

Change-Id: I1bf048df49c385a92fea55f99bd0a7c4283960cf
(cherry picked from commit 454cf61f8a191fc25a1d85d7be5df81eab405c54)
(cherry picked from commit 5f692dcca0a8b7cb60c9d250dbe3fa522d59425c)

commit_message:
Run validation only if overcloud exists.

When no overcloud is deployed, the openstack-endpoint.yaml validations
fail. This patch re-orders couple of tasks and runs the failing task for
unavailable endpoints only when an overcloud exists.

Change-Id: I174b5a239a7c1ab7b93323654a417db8f087bc27
Story: #2002061

commit_message:
Monkey patch original current_thread _active

Monkey patch the original current_thread to use the up-to-date _active
global variable. This solution is based on that documented at:
https://github.com/eventlet/eventlet/issues/592

Change-Id: Ifc6420d927c0ce9e04ff3b3253e81a474591e9bb
Closes-Bug: #1863021
(cherry picked from commit 5e9f694a5a8f90c72680acb1181318930f55aa30)
(cherry picked from commit 7196cfcb091d66856a1ca0db53816198249196db)
